DOC.HEAD: War Not Over, But Important Battle Won
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS one graf for 12th `Ojibwa Indians...' to UPDATE with agreement reached to lift one Indian blockade; pickup graf 13 `There are...'
DOC.HEAD: An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: For perhaps the first time in a century, North American Indians have taken up arms against the white man and won an important battle. The war is far from over, but the lesson from the six-week confrontation between Mohawks and the forces of law and order seems to be that violence and militancy get public attention _ and public attention leads to action. The situation has evolved considerably since July 11, when the provincial police launched an ill-advised attack on a small group of Mohawk militants blocking a road through Kanesatake reserve at Oka, just west of Montreal on the St. Lawrence River. The police were repulsed and an officer was killed, though it is still unclear by whom. To the south of Montreal, in the bedroom community of Chateauguay, Mohawks from the Kahnawake reserve set up a sympathy blockade, shutting down the Mercier bridge vital to commuters who work in the city. Since then there has been a steady war of nerves, growing anger on the part of frustrated south shore residents, three nights of rioting last week and on-again, off-again talks. On Thursday, serious negotiations finally got under way and the army began preparations over the weekend to replace the weary police on the barricades. Ostensibly, the fuss was over the village of Oka's plan to expand its nine-hole golf course on land the Indians claim is theirs, including a sacred burial ground. The golf course question was resolved when the federal government agreed to purchase the land and turn it over to the Mohawks. But the land claim issue is much wider and much more complicated here, and it goes far beyond the Mohawks at Kanesatake and Kahnawake. ``Any outcome at Oka short of a bloodbath will send a powerful message to native people across Canada whose grievances far outweigh those of Kanesatake,'' wrote University of Toronto historian Desmond Morton. ``Even the massive land claims settlement in the western Arctic, proudly announced last spring, is now in a state of collapse while native leaders wait to see whether Oka tactics produce better terms.'' Ojibwa Indians in Ontario jumped on the bandwagon and cut all east-west rail traffic to support their land claims. One band set up a blockade at Longlac and another group cut rail traffic east of White River, north of Lake Superior. However, authorities said Sunday that the Longlac group had agreed to end their blockade. There are thousands of Indian land claims pending before the federal government, covering about two-thirds of Canada's territory. The government actively processes only six at a time and typically settlements take 20 years or more. Quebec Premier Robert Bourassa, who called on the army for help, seems to have only two options, neither of them good. He can again try to dislodge the Indians by force, in front of a worldwide television audience and international observers. Or he can surrender to the pressure and negotiate with gun-toting militants who clearly have broken the law. He has opted for the second. The situation on the ground now is being watched by 24 observers from the Paris-based International Federation of Human rights. The negotiation process has been sealed off. The Quebec public was horrified last week when it saw a federal minister, a provincial minister and a judge sit down with armed, masked Indians to sign a document on a format for talks. The image remains indelible. ``Did you see that scene here with the ministers?'' lamented Yvan Patry, mayor of Oka Parish, which surrounds both the village of Oka and the Kanesatake reserve. Both sides in the conflict have clammed up since the beginning of talks. They say they have agreed not to speak about the negotiations, not even what is on the agenda. Tom Siddon, the federal minister of Indian affairs, claims that promises to reopen land claim talks with the Mohawks have nothing to do with the blockades in Oka and Chateauguay. ``I don't in any way agree with any suggestion that we have agreed to negotiate in the face of guns,'' said Siddon. ``We will not.'' Appearances, however, are to the contrary. The Kanesatake reserve is a patchwork of Indian territory with pieces separated by privately owned land. There had been earlier talks about finding a way to join up the various patches of Mohawk land. What the federal and provincial governments clearly fear is setting a dangerous precedent. ``Blockades will not result in any band being allowed to jump the queue in the claims process,'' the minister vowed. One thing is certain. The barricades will come down one day soon, and it appears likely that the band of Mohawk warriors who held off the forces of the white man will walk away with their heads held high and an inspiration for their brothers elsewhere. And that is, perhaps, the biggest concern of the Canadian authorities.

DOC.HEAD: `Space Baby' Wants to Trade Moon Trip for Earth Orbit
DOC.TEXT: The winner of a 1953 Space Baby contest has a deal for NASA: Instead of honoring her ``official'' ticket for a ride to the moon, let her orbit Earth aboard a space shuttle. Nancy Cavanagh, a fourth-grade teacher in Buckeye, Ariz., won the ticket seven years before the creation of NASA. She was judged the cutest baby at Redstone Arsenal Army Missile Command in Huntsville, now known as Redstone Arsenal. Her father, Bruce Carpenter, was an electrical engineer for Philco, an Army missile subcontractor. Today, NASA's Marshall Space Flight Center is on the base. ``I think it would be wonderful ... and NASA wouldn't have to take me as far as the ticket promises,'' Cavanagh said recently while in Huntsville to attend U.S. Space Camp, an educational program on space. ``I'd really like to go to the moon, but I'll settle for Earth orbit.'' ``NASA's not in the business of making trades like that,'' said flight center spokesman Don Amatore. ``But if she wants to apply for the Teacher-in-Space Program, I'm sure the agency would be glad to look at her application.'' The program was suspended after Challenger exploded in 1986. Its first participant, Christa McAuliffe, died with the rest of the shuttle's crew. Amatore said the program may someday resume.

DOC.TEXT: Stock priced bounced higher Monday morning despite deepening tension in the Middle East, while the dollar inched up against the yen. The dollar closed the morning session at 147.52 yen, up 0.17 yen from Friday's finish. It opened at 147.75 yen and fluctuated between 147.35 and 147.77. The benchmark Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues opened lower but rebounded in late morning trading to 26,920.77, up 134.05 points or 0.50 percent from Friday's close. The index had lost 762.72 points on Friday. On the bond market, the No. 119 10-year Japanese government bond was quoted at 83.25 points at 11:15 a.m. (10:15 p.m. Sunday EDT), up from Friday's close of 83.21. The yield was 8.05 percent, down from 8.06 percent. The dollar, which normally firms in times of international crisis, has now gained 0.87 yen since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. Traders said the dollar would remain stronger with the Mideast tension ongoing. Share prices bounced in thin trading late morning, fully recovering losses made early in the session. Index-linked buying helped lift the prices, dealers said. In the first section, an estimated 110 million shares changed hands, down from 170 million shares Friday morning. Losing issues outnumbered winning issues 532 to 302, while 208 issues remained unchanged. Meanwhile, North Sea Brent crude oil for October delivery was valued at $27-$27.20 a barrel, up from Friday's $26.10-$26.20.

DOC.HEAD: First U.S. Shots Fired, Foreigners Become Iraqi Trump Card
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with three grafs to UPDATE with U.N. Security Council resolution; Pickup 3rd pvs, `Iraq's statement...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto AMM7
DOC.TEXT:
U.S. warships fired the first shots by American forces in the Persian Gulf crisis in an unsuccessful effort to halt two Iraqi tankers, and Iraq said thousands of foreign captives will suffer first if a U.S. ``blockade'' curtails food. Iraq's threat, which singled out foreign babies and elderly people, was immediately denounced by the White House as an illegal ``use of innocent civilians as pawns'' in the Middle East standoff. The U.N. Security Council late Saturday unanimously demanded that Iraq let all foreigners leave and that Baghdad ``take no action to jeopardize the safety, security or health of such nationals.''
Iraq's statement, coupled with an earlier threat to use Americans and other foreigners as a defensive shield for Iraqi military installations, made it clear the foreigners have become a central part of Iraq's anti-U.S. strategy. Iraq said Saturday it had begun moving some of the foreigners to ``strategic'' locations around the country. In Washington, the Pentagon said the USS Reid fired six warning shots across the bow of the Iraqi ship Khanaqin in the Gulf of Oman after it ``refused repeated requests to halt.'' The shots were the first fired in the 2-day-old interdiction effort ordered by President Bush to halt goods leaving and entering Iraq. Also, the USS Bradley fired three warning shots across the bow of another Iraqi tanker to the north in the Persian Gulf and headed toward the Gulf of Oman, the Pentagon said. The Persian Gulf, which connects with the Gulf of Oman, is Iraq's outlet to the sea. ``Both tankers are currently under way, but are under close U.S. Navy surveillance,'' the Pentagon said. A Pentagon source who spoke on condition of anonymity said Navy ships were unlikely to take further action against the ships during nighttime hours. The Pentagon said the Iraqi vessels, which were heading out of the Persian Gulf area, were believed carrying Iraqi oil. Baghdad said the tankers were not hit and continued on their way, but that a similar act in the future will have ``grave consequences.'' Iraq's foreign minister, Tariq Aziz, said he did not consider the Iraqi treatment of foreigners an act of war, merely an attempt to prevent U.S. forces massing in Saudi Arabia from attacking Iraq or Kuwait. ``Foreigners would live with the Iraqis in some places that are the target of probable American aggression,'' Aziz told CBS News. ``That might deter the American government from committing the crime that the Iraqi people would like to avoid.'' In an interview Saturday with Britain's Independent Television News, Iraqi Ambassador to France Abdul Razzak al-Hachimi said in Paris: ``Some of them (the foreigners) ... have been distributed in strategic installations in Iraq starting all the way from north of Iraq to the south.'' Thomas R. Pickering, the U.S. ambassador to the United Nations, said later Saturday that Iraq's actions over the past 24 hours make it clear that Iraqi President Saddam Hussein is ``going to hold hostage all foreigners.'' U.S. officials had previously avoided using the word ``hostage'' to refer to the Americans and other foreigners trapped in Iraq and Kuwait. The British Foreign Office said 40 Britons, five Americans, four Germans and one French citizen were moved from Kuwaiti hotels to undisclosed locations. Aziz told CBS that Iraq will not use chemicals weapons unless the United States uses nuclear weapons in the conflict. However, Iraq's army newspaper on Saturday reiterated a threat to use weapons of ``mass destruction'' against any attacker, an apparent reference to Iraq's arsenal of long-range missiles, nerve gas and mustard gas. The United States, meanwhile, continued to pour thousands of troops into Saudi Arabia in an effort to build up a force that could withstand an invasion by tens of thousands of Iraqi soldiers massed on the Saudi-Kuwait border. For the first time since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2 and later annexed the emirate, U.S. troops stationed in the Saudi desert conducted maneuvers at night in temperatures that still hovered around 95 degrees. ``We're here sweating because our lives may depend on it,'' said one private who carried a 50-pound pack Friday night. ``But it's really not up to us. Our lives are in the politicians' hands.'' ``Finding the courage is tough,'' said a medic traveling with the soldiers. ``It's scary out here. But you've got to swallow that and go out and do it.'' In other developments: _President Bush prepared to call up military reserves to fill in the ranks of military doctors, cargo handlers and other specialists. An Army source said as many as 80,000 reservists and National Guardsmen could be activated. _The Pentagon launched an unprecedented diversion of civilian aircraft to bolster the U.S. military presence in the Middle East. _Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said the U.S. military commitment to Saudi Arabia's defense is ``long-term.'' ``Where we'll be a year or two from now, I wouldn't want to speculate,'' he said while en route to Saudi Arabia. _Iraq, which made peace overtures to Iran in order to devote its full attention to the standoff with the United States, withdrew thousands of troops from its Iranian border and said they would be deployed near Saudi Arabia. _Saudi Arabia said it is ready to increase its oil output by up to 2 million barrels a day to help offset the shortfall caused by the Iraqi invasion. But a Saudi minister said that would leave world markets 2 million barrels short of pre-invasion levels, and it may not halt soaring gas and oil prices. _Thousands of Arabs continued to reach Jordan after fleeing from Iraq and Iraq-occupied Kuwait. The only Westerners to get out were the few brave enough to dash for the border in private cars. The Baghdad government holds 3,000 Americans, 4,000 Britons and about 14,000 other Westerners among the more than 2 million foreigners caught in Iraq and Kuwait when Iraqi troops invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2.
DOC.HEAD: In its, 1st graf, a0619
Serviceman Says Some Military Don't Have Chemical Warfare Gear
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th graf to CLARIFY composition of unit and source's US base.
DOC.TEXT: About 120 troops stationed in Saudi Arabia are sitting in the ``front seat of Armageddon'' without weapons or equipment for chemical warfare, an non-commissioned officer said Saturday. ``I want to have a fighting chance. I don't have that,'' said Air Force Master Sgt. Johnnie Bratton in a phone interview from Dhahran on Saturday night. ``I'm ready to go out and do whatever I have to do but I don't have the minimum protection that is required.'' The thousands of American servicemen recently deployed to Saudi Arabia are equipped for chemical warfare, but those who have been there for months are not, he said. Bratton, a Vietnam veteran who has been in the military for 19{ years, said the Persian Gulf situation could evolve into another long conflict, and troops should be protected every way possible. ``We're in the front seat of Armaggedon,'' he said. Bratton, of San Marcos, said he and 120 other troops have been based at Dhahran, about 165 miles south of Kuwait, for up to two years on training missions. He said his unit was composed of Air Force, Army and Navy personnel and that he was based in Grand Forks, N.D., declining to disclose further details. Bratton said he decided to speak to the news media after pleas to his superiors, congressional leaders and others failed. The Pentagon had no immediate comment Saturday night. ``I don't have any knowledge of that,'' said Pentagon spokesman Lt. Col. Stuart Wagner.

DOC.HEAD: Iraqi Tankers Continue After U.S. Ships Fire Warnings
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS grafs 26-31 pvs, `The captain...early Wednesday' to CORRECT name of Sudan port, Saudi Arabian city; No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: EDITORS: The following story is partly based on a pool dispatch from journalists aboard the USS Eisenhower, with added detail from Washington.

U.S. Navy ships closely watched two Iraqi tankers late Saturday after the oil-carrying vessels ignored U.S. warning shots and headed out of the Persian Gulf area, U.S. military officials said. A Navy officer told reporters with Defense Secretary Dick Cheney aboard the USS Eisenhower in the Red Sea that the guided-missile frigate USS Reid fired the first shots of the two-day-old interdiction effort ordered by President Bush. The Pentagon later confirmed two Iraqi ships were warned with gunfire in separate incidents and that both continued under the watch of U.S. vessels. The Pentagon statement said both tankers were believed carrying Iraqi oil. Officials aboard the ships said U.S. forces briefly went to battle stations over the incidents. The U.S. operation is intended to halt goods leaving and entering Iraq in the Persian Gulf crisis. ``Both tankers are currently under way, but are under close U.S. Navy surveillance,'' according to a Pentagon statement issued late Saturday, when it was already past midnight in the gulf. A Pentagon official in Washington, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the Navy warships were unlikely to use any force against the tankers during nighttime hours. The USS Reid fired six warning shots across the bow of an Iraqi tanker that it intercepted in the Gulf of Oman, the Pentagon said. ``Initial reports indicate the Iraqi-flagged vessel Khanaqin refused repeated requests to halt,'' and the Reid then fired the warning shots, the Pentagon said. Also, the USS Bradley fired three warning shots across the bow of another Iraqi tanker after it refused U.S. requests to halt, the Pentagon said. The unidentified tanker was in the Persian Gulf, heading toward the Gulf of Oman. The only Iraqi port from which oil could be shipped is at the northern tip of the Persian Gulf, connected to the Gulf of Oman through the Strait of Hormuz. The gulf opens up into the Arabian Sea where oil-laden ships fan out to world ports. The Eisenhower is on the other side of Saudi Arabia in the Red Sea. In Baghdad, Iraq reported that the United States had fired on two Iraqi oil tankers that refused to be searched, and said a similar act in the future would have ``grave consequences.'' In the Red Sea, Capt. Morris Foote of the guided missile cruiser Ticonderoga said, ``One of our frigates, out in the Gulf of Oman, has fired a warning shot at an Iraqi tanker, in fact, fired six of them.'' The Ticonderoga was operating with the carrier Eisenhower in the Red Sea on the opposite side of the Saudi Arabian peninsula from the shooting incident. Foote later clarified that statement to say the shots were fired across the bow of the tanker. Foote said the Persian Gulf forces initially went to battle stations. The Eisenhower battle group, however, did not go on high alert status during the shooting incident, and he said the Iraqi tanker posed no apparent danger to U.S. forces. The Reid incident occurred about 4 p.m. local time (9 a.m. EDT), south of the narrow entrance to the Persian Gulf from the Gulf of Oman. Foote did not have details but other officers said they believed the Iraqi ship had not stopped when ordered. Foote said warning shots were fired by the Reid's 76 millimeter gun after the frigate's commander received permission to do so from Rear Adm. William Fogarty, commander of the Middle East task force in the Persian Gulf. Iraqi Oil Minister Issam Chalabi said in Baghdad that U.S. warships had fired on the Iraqi oil tanker Baba Karkar in the Persian Gulf and the oil tanker Khanaqin in the Gulf of Oman. Chalabi said the shots fell in front and behind the ships and they proceeded without stopping. Foote said there was apparently no threat from the Iraqi tanker in the Gulf of Oman, which like all other commercial vessels should not be armed. ``I don't think that there was any other provocation. I don't think there was anything, in fact, threatening from the Iraqis or from any other source,'' he said. ``But as a general course, when we start getting into the business of firing shots, you're never sure of the reaction,'' he said. On Thursday evening, President Bush authorized American warships to use force if necessary to stop commerce headed to and from Iraq and Kuwait, which is occupied by an estimated 160,000 Iraqi troops. Defense Department spokesman Pete Williams, accompanying Cheney aboard the Eisenhower at the beginning of a four-day trip to the region, refused to comment on the situation. Cheney was not available for comment. While on board the destroyer USS Scott, Cheney was told that the Scott had just returned from its interdiction duty at the mouth of the Gulf of Aqaba and had turned back a Cypriot bulk freighter headed for the port. The captain of the Scott said the Cypriot freighter was headed for the port of Aqaba and had departed from Port Sudan, Sudan's main Red Sea port. Scott Commander Tom Corcoran said he had a ``very polite conversation'' with the master of the Cypriot ship and the freighter turned around after reporting that it was carrying a cargo of aluminum chromate and other chemicals. ``We didn't want to take the chance. We maneuvered at a safe but fairly close distance and spoke on the radio,'' Corcoran told pool reporters. He said the ship turned around and headed for an unknown destination. Cheney was to remain on the Eisenhower until Sunday morning when he was to travel to northern Saudi Arabia and visit American troops deployed on land in the defense of the desert kingdoms' vital oil fields. He was to travel on to Bahrain, and several other Persian Gulf nations before visiting in Jiddah on Monday and stopping in Cairo before arriving back in Washington early Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: U.N. Security Council Demands That Iraq Release Foreigners
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS two grafs after 14th pvs, `Iraqi Ambassador...' to UPDATE with comment from Iraqi, Kuwaiti ambassadors; Pickup 15th, `Saturday's resolution...'
DOC.TEXT: The U.N. Security Council on Saturday unanimously demanded that Iraq let all foreigners leave, and the U.S. ambassador accused Baghdad of holding them ``hostage.'' Concern about thousands of Americans, West Europeans and Japanese trapped in Iraq and Kuwait heightened after Iraq said Friday foreigners from ``aggressive nations'' would be used as defensive shields for Iraqi military installations. On Saturday, Iraq said some foreigners were moved to ``strategic installations'' around the country. It also said the foreigners, including babies and the elderly, would be among the first to suffer the privations of the U.N.-ordered embargo on Iraq. In its resolution Saturday, the Security Council ``demands that Iraq permit and facilitate the immediate departure from Kuwait and Iraq of the nationals of third countries and grant immediate and continuing access of consular officials to such nationals.'' The resolution also demands that ``Iraq take no action to jeopardize the safety, security or health of such nationals.'' All 15 members of the council voted for the resolution. Yemen, the only Arab nation on the council, voted for the resolution, but its ambassador, Mohamed A. Sallam, said food should be allowed into Iraq. The U.N. sanctions allow food and medicine shipments to Iraq for humanitarian purposes. Meanwhile, U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar dispatched two senior U.N. officials to Baghdad to urge Iraqi officials to safeguard the foreigners and let them leave. Earlier Saturday, U.S. Ambassador Thomas R. Pickering denounced the latest moves by Iraqi President Saddam Hussein. ``We are now responding to the three steps which Saddam Hussein has taken in the last 24 hours, including beginning a process of sequestering foreign nationals, the announcement that he was going to use them as military shields, and finally the statement this morning in which it was clear he was going to hold hostage all foreigners.'' U.S. officials had previously avoided using the word ``hostage'' to describe the Americans and other foreigners trapped since the Aug. 2 Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. Asked if he was aware of anyone being harmed or in danger in Iraq or occupied Kuwait, Pickering said the United States was concerned about people who might need routine medical treatment. Iraqi Ambassador Abdul Amir al-Anbari, speaking before the Security Council, said the economic embargo of his country is ``unjust'' and called the U.S. ``blockade'' of food and medicines to Iraqis a ``terrorist act.'' ``Iraq will not prevent foreign nationals from obtaining foodstuffs and medicines; it will share with foreign nationals what comes in,'' al-Anbari said. The representative of the ousted Kuwaiti government, Mohammad Saad Al Sallal, told the council the resolution addresses a situation ``unprecedented in the whole history of the international community ... the taking thousands, rather millions of citzens of many countries as ransom.'' Saturday's resolution was the fourth passed by the council condemning Iraq since the invasion. The council previously denounced the Iraqi invasion, imposed the trade embargo and rejected the annexation of Kuwait. In the resolution, the council again declared the annexation of Kuwait ``null and void, and therefore demands that the government of Iraq rescind its orders for the closure of diplomatic and consular missions in Kuwait and the withdrawal of the immunity of their personnel. ...'' Iraq has ordered all embassies in Kuwait to close, claiming the country is now part of Iraq and diplomats should only be accredited in Baghdad. U.N. spokesman Fred Eckhard said Perez de Cuellar is sending two undersecretary-generals to Baghdad to discuss freedom of movement for the foreigners in Iraq and Kuwait. The two U.N. officials, whom he did not name, are expected to arrive in Baghdad early Monday. The Baghdad government holds 3,000 Americans, 4,000 Britons and about 14,000 other Westerners among the more than 2 million foreigners caught in Iraq and Kuwait when Iraq invaded Kuwait. Thousands of Arabs, East Europeans and Soviets and Asians have been allowed to cross into Jordan. A U.S.-led multinational force and an Arab force have been deployed to keep Iraq from attacking Saudi Arabia and to impose the trade embargo on Iraq. A statement read over Iraqi television and radio Saturday referred to the U.S.-led quarantine as ``an act of war,'' and said that as food and medicine become scarce, supplies will be set aside for the military. ``We're outraged,'' Ambassador Sir Crispin Tickell of Britain said earlier Saturday. ``It's almost incredible something like that could happen.''

DOC.HEAD: Three Youths Convicted in Jogger Trial
DOC.NOTE: Eds: STANDS as 7th Ld-Writethru to AM-Central Park Jogger, a0657. SUBS 10th graf to CORRECT that only two of remaining three defendants are free on bond. ^LaserPhoto NY28
DOC.TEXT: Three teen-agers were convicted Saturday of raping and assaulting a woman jogger who was brutalized and left for dead in Central Park by a marauding gang of youths. The defendants _ Antron McCray, 16, Yusef Salaam, 16 and Raymond Santana, 15 _ were found innocent of sodomy and of attempted murder, the most serious charge in the much-publicized case. They also were convicted of riot. The three were jailed without bail. As juveniles, they faced a maximum of 10 years in prison at sentencing Sept. 11. The 30-year-old jogger was found lying senseless in a pool of blood after the April 19, 1989, attack. In a coma for two weeks, she recovered enough to return to her investment banking job and give dramatic testimony at the trial. The jury spent 10 days in deliberations, the last three convincing one holdout who believed McCray was innocent. It also took three days to consider the attempted murder charges, said juror Charles Nestorick. The jury finally decided to acquit because they believed the teen-agers didn't intend to kill. ``Youths that age are not well versed in how many blows it takes to kill someone,'' Nestorick said. The case created enormous sympathy for the victim, whose name was not printed by most newspapers. The defendants also had supporters, who demonstrated outside the courthouse regularly, charging racism because the victim was white and wealthy, the youths black or Hispanic. Defense attorneys claimed police lied and threatened Santana and McCray into making videotaped confessions. Salaam did not sign a written statement or make a videotaped statement. Prosecutors said the three defendants were part of a gang of as many as 30 youths who rampaged through the park, harassing at least nine people. Three other teen-agers charged in the assault on the woman await trial. Two are free on bond. Salaam, McCray and Santana also were convicted of assault and robbery for attacks on two male joggers, John Loughlin and David Lewis. The woman was jogging through the northern end of the park when she was attacked. She was dragged about 70 feet into the woods, gang-raped and bashed repeatedly with a brick and pipe. She recovered enough to resume work _ and jogging _ within eight months of the attack. She is a vice president for Salomon Brothers, a Wall Street firm. In a statement after the verdict, Mayor David Dinkins said the attack ``seared the soul of every decent New Yorker.'' ``We should recommit ourselves to building a city and forging a society in which such heinous crimes do not occur,'' he said. While the woman's recovery was inspirational to many New Yorkers, a few activists, including the Rev. Al Sharpton, claimed police arrested the youths because most were black. Earlier Saturday, the jurors had asked for the fourth time to see McCray's videotaped statement, in which he told police he kicked the jogger and feigned sex with her to impress his friends. McCray's father, Bobby McCray, testified he encouraged his son to lie to police because he was led to believe there was an agreement that would allow his son to go free. The detective who took the statement said no deal was offered. Another detective testified that Santana told him he counted 33 youths who entered the park shortly after 9 p.m. on the night of the attack to ``beat up and rip off joggers and cyclists.'' When the group saw the female jogger on her nightly six-mile run, ``We all charged her,'' McCray said on the videotape. She struggled and screamed as several teen-agers dragged her from the paved drive down a wooded slope into the darkness, he said. The defendants told detectives the naked woman was struck with a metal pipe, bashed in the head and face with a brick, cut on the legs with a knife and sexually attacked in a frenzy of violence, assistant District Attorney Elizabeth Lederer said. The trial's most riveting moment came when the jogger took the witness stand. She walked unsteadily before describing the lasting effects of the attack: trouble with balance and sight, no sense of smell, a six-week stretch of amnesia. The rampaging youths went on to attack several other people _ Loughlin, a teacher, hospitalized for two days with his injuries; Lewis, a banker, who escaped serious injury because of his speed; and John Goode, a British Airways employee who was punched. Medical workers testified the woman had lost about three-quarters of her blood and was near death when she arrived at a hospital. She later was transferred to a Connecticut rehabilitation center. The jurors criticized Salaam's attorney, Robert Burns, for putting his client on the stand. ``It shot down everything he had going for him because his story was so far-fetched,'' Nestorick said.

DOC.HEAD: Pentagon Readies for Reserves Call-Up As First Shots Fired
DOC.NOTE: EDS: INSERTS 2 grafs after 6th graf bgng The Pentagon xxx to UPDATE with Iraqi report of third firing; picks up 7th graf pvs bgng In a statement.
DOC.TEXT: The Pentagon geared up for expected activation of thousands of reserves as U.S. warships began attempting to enforce an embargo against Iraq on Saturday, firing warning shots at two Iraqi oil tankers and shadowing them as they sailed away under cover of darkness. President Bush could activate as many as 80,000 members of the Army Reserve and the Army National Guard to bolster the U.S. military buildup in the Middle East, which Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said could last for years. But the actual number was likely to be much less, said an Army source, speaking on the condition of anonymity. The source said 80,000 was a ``tentative upper limit planning figure.'' The shots were the first fired by American forces in the Persian Gulf crisis following Bush's order Thursday to interdict shipments in and out of Iraq, using ``the minimum force necessary.'' Iraqi Oil Minister Issam Chalabi said the shots fell in front of and behind the two tankers, the Baba Karkar in the Persian Gulf and the Khanaqin in the Gulf of Oman, and they proceeded without stopping. The Pentagon said Navy ships were closely monitoring the two Iraqi tankers heading out of the Persian Gulf area and believed to be carrying Iraqi oil. Military sources said it was unlikely the Navy would take any further action against the ships during the night, which settled over the region a few hours after the initial incidents. But the Iraqi News Agency said a third Iraqi tanker was fired upon Sunday as it sailed in the central part of the Gulf. It did not say in which direction the ship was heading, or name the U.S. warship that allegedly fired the shots Sunday. The report could not be immediately confirmed independently, and a Pentagon spokesman, Marine Lt. Col. Stuart Wagner, said, ``Nothing has been called into the Pentagon about it. We have not been notified of any such incident.'' In a statement, the Pentagon said the USS Reid fired six warning shots across the bow of an Khanaqin in the Gulf of Oman after it ``refused repeated requests to halt.'' Also, the USS Bradley fired three warning shots across the bow of another Iraqi tanker in the Persian Gulf and headed toward the Gulf of Oman, the Pentagon said. ``Both tankers are currently under way, but are under close U.S. Navy surveillance,'' the Pentagon said. Iraq's only port is nestled at the northernmost tip of the Persian Gulf, which connects with the Gulf of Oman through the Strait of Hormuz. Beyond the Gulf of Oman is the Arabian Sea and, beyond that, the open waters of the Indian Ocean. Meanwhile, fears mounted that Iraqi President Saddam Hussein was using U.S. citizens and other foreign nationals in Iraq and occupied Kuwait as weapons in his battle to defeat UN-sponsored economic sanctions. The Iraqi government announced that the sanctions were causing shortages of food, including milk for babies. It said ``the same calamity'' would befall the thousands of foreign nationals, including babies, under Iraqi control because the government considered the sanctions ``an act of war.'' The White House said it was deeply concerned by Iraq's latest moves. ``The use of innocent civilians as pawns to promote what Iraq sees to be its self-interest is contrary to international law and indeed to all accepted norms of international conduct,'' presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said from Kennebunkport, Maine. An estimated 3,000 Americans are in Iraq and Kuwait. Bush, vacationing in Kennebunkport, was preparing to sign an executive order to authorize the call-up of thousands of Army, Navy and Air Force reserves. Officials said he had decided a call-up was necessary, but details of how many and from which reserve units were still being worked out. A wide variety of tasks are assigned to reserve forces, from cargo handling and medical support to aerial refueling and infantry operations. The Army, Navy and Air Force are heavily dependent on the reserves during a large-scale mobilization. A reserve call-up shows the magnitude of the U.S. military commitment in Saudi Arabia, which Cheney described as ``long term'' and said might last for years. ``Where we'll be a year or two from now, I wouldn't want to speculate,'' Cheney told reporters Friday en route to the desert kingdom. Cheney was on a four-day swing through several gulf nations to visit U.S. soldiers, sailors and airmen and to talk with government officials. A decision to activate reserves is fraught with domestic political risk because of a public perception that it is tantamount to putting the nation on a war footing. Cheney had recommended to Bush that he use his authority to call as many as 200,000 armed services reserves to active duty. It would be the first reserve call-up for military action since President Johnson activated 35,000 reserves in 1968 following the Tet offensive in Vietnam and the seizure by North Korea of the U.S. surveillance ship Pueblo. Some reservists would be deployed to U.S. military installations and ports to help with the transportation of troops and equipment to Saudi Arabia. Others may make the trip to the Arabian desert as part of the U.S. combat force. Reserves provide more than two-thirds of wartime medical personnel support, three-quarters of medical evacuation crews and nearly all of the Navy's search and rescue operations. In a further indication of the enormous scale of the U.S. military deployment, the Pentagon on Friday night announced it was commandeering up to 38 airplanes from 29 commercial carriers to help ferry troops and cargo to the Middle East. It was the first time the Pentagon has exercised its contractual right to use the Civil Reserve Air Fleet in the 38 year that the program has existed. And on Saturday, the Navy issued a formal statement confirming earlier acknowledgment from Pentagon sources that the aircraft carrier USS Kennedy was being dispatched to the Middle East. Also, the head of the Military Sealift Command said the Navy, which runs the sea-transport system, chartered four commercial merchant ships to bolster its fleet of vessels ferrying supplies, weapons and equipment to Saudi Arabia. Admiral Francis Donovan said in an interview that more commercial ships would be needed in the days ahead. He said the overall sealift was operating satisfactorily. He declined to provide exact details of the sealift, but said nine ships prepositioned near Guam and the Indian Ocean island of Diego Garcia were carrying enough supplies to Saudi Arabia to sustain 33,000 Marines for 30 days.

DOC.HEAD: PRECEDE Manama
Iraq Calls U.S. Actions `Piracy'; Pentagon: No Reports of New Shots
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with no confirmation of shots fired Sunday from Pentagon; No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz on Sunday called U.S. shipping inderdiction efforts ``piracy and armed aggression'' and called on the international community to condemn it, the Iraqi News Agency said. Aziz sent a letter to U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar complaining about U.S. warships firing shots toward Iraqi oil tankers that refused to stop, according to the news agency, monitored in Nicosia. ``American warships intercepted and inspected and fired shots against our tankers Saturday and Sunday,'' Aziz said. ``Such acts are clear proofs that America is permitting itself to commit piracy and armed aggression on high seas against Iraq.'' U.S. warships on Saturday fired on two Iraqi oil-bearing tankers, but shipping sources and the Pentagon were unable to confirm a third incident Sunday. Pentagon spokesman, Marine Lt. Col. Stuart Wagner, said: ``Nothing has been called into the Pentagon about it. We have not been notified of any such incident.'' Shipping sources said they had not monitored gunshots but that they were checking with other points along the Gulf. ``It must be just too far from our monitoring radios,'' said one executive in the southern Gulf. The Iraqi News Agency said the third Iraqi tanker was fired upon Sunday as it sailed in the central part of the Gulf, but did not say in which direction the ship was heading, or name the U.S. warship that allegedly fired the shots. According to the Iraqi News Agency, Aziz said his government wanted the U.N. to guarantee ``measures that prevent America from exercising the police role in international waters.'' American warships were monitoring the movements of two Iraqi oil tankers early Sunday after the vessels ignored U.S. warning shots and headed out of the Gulf region. A U.S. Navy officer told reporters with Defense Secretary Dick Cheney aboard the USS Eisenhower in the Red Sea that the guided-missile frigate USS Reid fired the first shots Saturday of a two-day-old interdiction effort ordered by President George Bush. In Washington, the U.S. Defense Department later confirmed that two Iraqi ships had been warned with gunfire in separate incidents and that both continued sailing under the watch of the naval vessels. On Saturday, The USS Reid fired six warning shots across the bow of an Iraqi tanker that it intercepted in the Gulf of Oman, the Pentagon said. Later, the USS Bradley fired three warning shots across the bow of another Iraqi tanker that refused U.S. requests to halt, the Pentagon said. The unidentified tanker was in the Persian Gulf, heading toward the Gulf of Oman. U.S. forces are in the Persian Gulf region to enforce U.N.-imposed economic sanctions against Iraq designed to force that country to withdraw from Kuwait, which it invaded on Aug. 2 and later annexed.

DOC.HEAD: Leftists, Neo-Nazis Brawl on Anniversary of Hess' Death
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of neo-Nazis marking the death of Rudolf Hess brawled with a group of leftists in the southern West German town where the former Hitler deputy is buried. Police said they arrested 46 people for assault, property damage, and other incidents. About 1,000 right-wing extremists gathered in Wunsiedel on Saturday to mark the third anniversary of Hess' death. About 4,000 leftists took part in a counterdemonstration, and clashes broke out between the two groups, police said. Hess, a native of Wunseidel, is buried in a cemetery in town. Police blocked off the graveyard on the anniversary of his death. Hess was deputy leader of the Nazis when he flew to Scotland in 1941 to negotiate a separate peace with Britain. He was jailed until 1946, when he was convicted at the Nuremberg war crimes trials and sent to Berlin's Spandau prison until his death.

DOC.HEAD: Defense Minster to Halt Army Training of PLO Members
DOC.TEXT: Under heavy criticism from Jewish groups, East Germany's defense minister said Sunday he will halt army training of members of the Palestine Liberation Organization. Defense Minister Rainer Eppelmann said he was stopping the training on Monday but that the government still must make a declaration of principle to end the training permanently. He said the East German army currently provides training to 31 PLO members, 29 Libyans and 130 Yemenis. He said none of the trainees were involved in training for terror acts. On Friday, West Berlin's Jewish community sharply criticized the training program and demanded it be stopped. Community leader Heinz Galiniski said it was unbelievable that the practice of training the PLO had not been discontinued after the former Communist government was toppled last year.

DOC.HEAD: 162,750 Quit Russian Communist Party in July
DOC.TEXT: The head of the Russian branch of the Communist Party was quoted Sunday as saying 162,750 members quit in July, about 1.5 percent of the 11 million Communist Party members in the republic. The figures were announced by Ivan Polozkov, a hard-liner who was elected in June to lead the Russian branch. Polozkov was quoted by the Sovietskaya Rossiya (Soviet Russia) newspaper. He said he was concerned by the number of drop-outs, particularly since 90,000 of them were the very factory workers that the Communist Party claims to represent. Many had predicted mass defections after the Russian party congress in June, which was dominated by hard-liners opposed to many of the democratic and market-oriented reforms favored by Mikhail S. Gorbachev. Gorbachev is both president of the country and head of the national Communist Party. Some reformers are planning to quit the party in autumn when they form an alternative party and make a bid for a share of the Communists' vast financial resources.

DOC.HEAD: About 20,000 Passengers Stranded by Train Protests
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of demonstrators protesting plans to bring high-speed trains to the scenic Provence region occupied stations and barricaded tracks, stranding about 20,000 passengers, officials said Sunday. The demonstrators disrupted rail service for several hours in the Saturday evening protest. Police cleared the last occupied stations at Miramas, Senas and Sain-Martin-de-Crau shortly after midnight, but rail officials said service would probably not return to normal before midday Sunday. The protest was the largest in a series of demonstrations to prevent the expansion of the high-speed trains into Provence. Protesters fear a new high-speed line through Provence to Marseille would destroy the region's scenic beauty and its important wine industry. On Saturday, Transportation Minister Michel Delebarre promised new studies to find the route least damaging to the environment. But he stopped short of saying the $180 million project would be canceled. Railroad officials say the new line, if completed, would cut travel time between Paris and Marseille to three hours, a reduction of 1 hour, 40 minutes. The high-speed locomotives travel at about 200 mph.

DOC.HEAD: Begin Leaving Jerusalem, Moving to Tel Aviv Hospital
DOC.TEXT: Former Prime Minister Menachem Begin was discharged from a Jerusalem hospital Sunday and was moving to Tel Aviv at the request of his family, hospital officials said. Begin, who turned 77 two weeks ago, has been recovering from a broken right hip at Jerusalem's Sharei Zedek Hospital since he fell in his living room July 3. Dr. Arnold Rosen, head of the hospital's geriatric department, described Begin's condition as ``good, very good even.'' Hospital Spokeswoman Orna Cohen said Begin's family had suggested he move to Tel Aviv, where he could be visited daily by his daughters, one of whom lives in the coastal city. Begin was moved to Tel Aviv's Ichilov Hospital and was expected to move later into an apartment, Ms. Cohen said. Begin maintained a residence in Tel Aviv until his election as prime minister in 1977. He had been living in virtual seclusion in a Jerusalem apartment since resigning as prime minister on Sept. 14, 1983. At the time of his sudden resignation, he was believed to be depressed over Israel's military involvement in Lebanon and the death of his wife, Aliza, in November 1982. Begin has two daughters, Leah and Hassia, and a son, Binyamin, who is a leading member of Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's right-wing Likud bloc.

DOC.HEAD: Israeli Troops Clash with Jordanian Soldiers, One Killed
DOC.TEXT: Israeli soldiers killed one Jordanian soldier and wounded another Sunday after the Jordanians infiltrated into the occupied West Bank, the military command said. No Israeli troops were injured in the clash, the command said. The incident occurred when a routine army patrol in the West Bank found footprints south of the Adam Bridge over the Jordan river, the army said. The area is about 15 miles north of Jericho. An army statement said the Israeli patrol ``identified two armed people in Jordanian army uniforms. The two were ordered to halt but did not, and opened fire at the Israeli troops.'' ``The soldeirs returned fire and in the exchange of gunfire one of the Jordanian soldiers was killed and the other slightly wounded,'' the statement said. The wounded soldier was captured and was being interrogated. The army statement did not link the infiltration to the current tensions involving Iraq. Attempted infiltrations often occur on the Jordanian-Israeli frontier, and several times the infiltrators have been Jordanian soldiers acting on their own. The army said it was the second infiltration of Jordanian soldiers into Israel this year. There have also been three shooting incidents from Jordanian territory, the army said. No Israeli soldiers were injured in any of these incidents.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Saddam to Use Foreigners as Shield, Offers Trade to Bush
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 5 grafs to UPDATE with Saddam offering to let foreigners go if Bush pulls out troops and backs off on embargo. Pickup 5th, `U.S. warships...'
DOC.TEXT: President Saddam Hussein of Iraq said on Sunday that he will hold Westerners who have been detained since the Kuwaiti invasion at vital targets in Iraq to avert a ``catastrophe'' that might result from a U.S.-led attack. But he offered to let the foreigners leave if President Bush offers written guarantees that American forces will be withdrawn from Saudi Arabia and that the embargo imposed on Iraq after it invaded Kuwait will be lifted. Earlier Iraqi government statements had said the foreigners would be used as a shield for Iraqi military installations, and that they would suffer first if an international embargo on Iraq causes shortages of food and medicine. Sunday's statement, broadcast on Iraqi television and translated by The Associated Press, was described as an open letter to the families of the thousands of foreigners, including 3,000 Americans, trapped in Iraq and Kuwait. Saddam also defended detaining the foreigners, blamed Western powers for causing the Persian Gulf crisis, and reiterated Iraq's longstanding historical claims to Kuwait, which it annexed six days after its invasion three weeks ago. U.S. warships on Saturday fired warning shots at two Iraqi oil tankers, one in the Persian Gulf and one further south in the Gulf of Oman. The official Iraqi News Agency claimed that U.S. warships fired on another Iraqi tanker Sunday as it sailed in the central Persian Gulf, but the Pentagon and shipping sources in the region could not confirm the report. Elsewhere in the gulf, an official in the Jordanian port of Aqaba said U.S. warships prevented a Sudanese ferry from entering the port Sunday to pick up 550 Sudanese who had escaped from Iraq and Iraqi-occupied Kuwait. The official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said U.S. warships also searched a Chinese freighter Sunday before allowing it to enter the port. Although Jordan has said it will enforce an international embargo on Iraqi goods, heavy trucks with Iraqi license plates continue to load goods from docked ships and warehouses in the port area and drive them back to Iraq. The embargo was imposed after Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. Since overrunning Kuwait, Iraq has mined Kuwait's oil ports and placed explosives in Kuwait City's electric and water plants, according to a report from official Radio France International that quoted Egyptian engineers. Refugees fleeing occupied Kuwait said on Sunday that a Kuwaiti resistance fighter carried out a suicide car bomb attack Friday on Iraqi forces near a hospital in a suburb of Kuwait City. A clandestine Kuwait radio station said an unspecified number of Iraqi soldiers died or were wounded in the attack. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said Sunday that Iraq has massed 200,000 troops and more than 1,000 tanks on the Saudi border and that U.S. forces in the region are there to defend the oil-rich nation from a possible Iraqi attack. Cheney spoke to servicemen aboard the USS Eisenhower in the Red Sea. At another stop at a military base in Saudi Arabia, Cheney refused to say how many U.S. troops have been rushed to the kingdom, but he said they should be able to repulse an attack ordered by Saddam. ``Should Saddam Hussein be foolish enough to launch an attack on Saudi Arabia, we would be able to do a very effective job of making him pay a bit of a price for that,'' Cheney said. But he added, ``Obviously, I'll be more comfortable once we've got more forces in the country.'' Also Sunday, the Gulf Cooperation Council alliance was to meet in Jiddah, Saudi Arabia, sources said, to consider sending troops to help defend member nations, who include Saudi Arabia, Bahrain and the United Arab Emirates. The latest Iraqi statements, carried by the Iraqi News Agency, came amid growing international anxiety over the fate of an estimated 21,000 Westerners, including 3,000 Americans, who were trapped in Iraq and Kuwait by the invasion. The statements also came just hours after the U.N. Security Council unanimously demanded that Iraq let all foreigners leave and ``take no action to jeopardize the safety, security or health of such nationals.'' In one statement carried by the news agency, Iraq singled out ``Western foreigners and Australians'' living in three cities in Kuwait for assembly at three hotels in the capital, Kuwait City. It said the measure was to secure their safety and ``Anyone who does not comply will, together with his government, bear full responsibility for any undesirable action that might be targeted against them by hostile elements.'' Westerners in Kuwait City, Al-Nidaa and Al-Jahrah were ordered to assemble at the Hyatt Regency, the Meridian and the International, according to the statement, monitored in Nicosia, Cyprus. Al-Jahrah is the site of a former Kuwaiti military air base west of Kuwait City, but the location of Al-Nidaa could not immediately be determined. Radio France International also reported Sunday that Iraq has moved some Westerners to Kuwaiti oil installations to prevent them from being attacked. The Iraqi statement was the second such asssembly order in four days. On Thursday, American and British nationals in Kuwait were ordered to report to hotels, but no Iraqi officials were there to meet the few who showed up. On Saturday, Iraq said foreigners would be the first to suffer if the embargo results in shortages of food and medicine in Iraq. On Friday, Iraq said foreigners may be placed around Iraqi military installaions to prevent U.S. forces in the region from attacking them. On Sunday, the Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz called U.S. shipping interdiction efforts ``piracy and armed aggression'' and demanded the international community condemn them, the Iraqi News Agency said. In a letter to U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar on Sunday, Aziz protested the warning shots fired at Iraqi tankers, the news agency said. ``Such acts are clear proofs that America is permitting itself to commit piracy and armed aggression on high seas against Iraq,'' the letter said. Two U.S. destroyers, meanwhile, steamed through the Suez Canal on Sunday on their way to the Red Sea, a canal official said. The official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the John Rodgers, a destroyer, and the Tattnall, a guided missile destroyer, had entered the waterway and would exit the canal later Sunday.

DOC.HEAD: Israel Tense Over Reported Jordanian Military Alert, Hussein's Stand
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Israel officials said Sunday that Jordan has declared a top-level military alert and is recruiting more than 80,000 volunteers for the Iraqi army _ moves that have confused Israel and heightened tension in the region. A senior government official said the Jordanian actions follow repeated signals from Israel that it has no intention of attacking the neighboring country. The official, speaking on condition of anonymity, told The Associated Press Israeli intelligence analysts have concluded that a U.S.-Iraqi military conflict is imminent. He said analysts also believe that Iraq is likely to use Palestinian terror groups for attacks on U.S. targets in the Middle East. Speaking of Jordan, the official said ``the army has been placed on the highest possible level of alert and is ready for war. What war, we don't understand.'' The official declined to specify what steps have been taken by Jordan's military. But a reporter who arrived from Jordan last week said police and army leaves were cancelled and civil defense was being organized in the Jordan Valley, along the 225-mile border with Israel. In Jordan's capital of Amman, rumors of impending mobilization of reserves circulated among the population, the reporter added. The Israeli official said Israel was unable to comprehend the Jordanian moves and was worried that Jordan's King Hussein may be losing control. ``After knowing this guy for 37 years we suddenly come to a point when we don't understand what he does,'' he said. ``But maybe it does not matter what the king says or does anymore, because he may not be in control.'' Hussein has remained Iraq's closest ally throughout the Persian Gulf crisis. Israel is concerned that Iraq may eventually use Jordan as a platform from which to attack the Jewish state and has warned that the entrance of Iraqi troops into the kingdom would mean war. The official expressed concern that King Hussein, known as a moderate, may now be swept up in the wave of pro-Iraqi enthusiasm in Jordan. He cited mass rallies in support of Iraq's President Saddam Hussein, persistent pro-Iraqi propaganda by the Jordanian media, and the registration of some 80,000 Jordanians who have volunteered to serve in the army of Iraq. The official said King Hussein ``is definitely in alliance with Saddam. He is agitating pro-Iraqi sentiments and definitely did not agree to fully blockade Aqaba,'' Jordan's Red Sea port and a principle supply route for Iraq. As one sign of increasing tension, the official noted Sunday's firefight between an Israeli military patrol and two Jordanian soldiers who infiltrated into Israel. One Jordanian was shot to death and another wounded and captured. ``We expect more such clashes,'' the official said. Some Israeli military analysts said Jordan's military actions could be explained by fear of an Israeli preemptive strike. ``The Jordanian action is a prudent one. They are worried about a possible Israeli preemptive strike. I would do the same thing in their place,'' said Ron Ben-Ishai, military commentator for the daily Yediot Ahronot. But the government official said Israel had repeatedly assured King Hussein that it had no aggressive intentions. ``We have sent all kinds of signals to calm him,'' the official said. As part of its effort to reassure Jordan, the government has requested officials to avoid alarming statements, such as claims by right-wing politicians that a Palestinian state should be created in Jordan, the government official said. ``We are definitely not saying anything that we know can provoke more worry on the part of King Hussein,'' he said. Turning to the gulf, the official said Israeli intelligence has concluded that ``the Americans are preparing for a military strike, and we believe Saddam will resist.'' He said it was still unclear who will start a shooting war. But Saddam was prepared to use Palestinian terrorist groups for attacks on American targets, ``including those in Saudi Arabia,'' the official said. He said the organizations likely to be used include the radical Abu Nidal group, Abul Abbas' Palestine Liberation Front and perhaps other factions of the Palestine Liberation Organization.

DOC.HEAD: Work to Begin on Razed Historic District Two Years After Fire
Am AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: Many people wept when fire razed historic Chiado, where the shop windows were full of dreams and cafes echoed with endless debate of art and politics. Two years later, rebuilding is about to begin. Lisbon received messages of sympathy from cities and national governments after the fire. It was showered with offers of help in recovering from a ``cultural disaster.'' Gone were the Cafe Ferrari, scene of much good conversation and passionate argument; window shopping on the Rua do Carmo; the smell of roasting chestnuts in the old streets. Now, the man who will direct the reconstruction says it may have been a blessing in disguise. ``When the Chiado burned, the first news that went around the world was `disaster. . . . In fact, it was bad, but not that bad,'' Alvaro Siza Vieira, Portugal's leading architect, said in an interview. Siza is ready to begin a $74 million rebuilding project in the 10-block downtown area that is expected to take three years. The goal is ``regeneration of an area that before the fire was a bit ill and dilapidated,'' he said, strolling through the ruins of the Grandela department store, where the fire started Aug. 25, 1988. It raged for more than a day, killing two people, injuring 40, leaving 300 homeless and 6,000 temporarily out of work. Only charred ruins remained of such landmarks as the Ferrari cafe, specialty grocers Costa e Martins and the 350-year-old Casa Batalha button shop on Rua Garrett. The disaster inspired a debate worthy of the Ferrari on topics ranging from city planning to safety standards. Most of the wood-frame buildings had no fire sprinklers. Stone terraces in a new pedestrian mall kept fire trucks away from the heart of the blaze. Many Lisbon residents, proud of the beauty of a city stretching over seven hills along the shimmering Tagus estuary, worried that modern office blocks might be built in the old Baixa, or lower town. In 1985, controversial architect Tomas Taveira shocked the city by building the Amoreiras, a massive, pastel-colored shopping, apartment and office complex, atop one of the city's hills. The Amoreiras is a commercial success, but few Lisbon inhabitants say they like its style. Faced with this traditional-modern rivalry, Siza departed from the contemporary, ascetic style that won him the Alvar Aalto international architecture award in 1988. ``It would have been wrong to use an accident to make an island of modern architecture in the historic center'' of Lisbon, he said. Chiado will look much the same as before, he said, because 18 of the 20 charred facades now propped by scaffolding can be saved, but there will be ``new, hidden improvements'' and the district ``won't be a museum.'' The project, approved by Mayor Jorge Sampaio last month, includes a luxury hotel and small-scale shopping malls behind the facades. Up to 40 percent of space on upper floors of reconstructed buildings will be devoted to apartments, ``to keep people in the Chiado, not offices,'' the architect said. A new subway station will link the district with the Baixa, which was rebuilt on a grid system by the Marquis of Pombal after an earthquake destroyed most of Lisbon in 1755. One victim of the quake was the Carmo convent. Siza plans a pedestrian ramp leading up to the convent ruins, which have become part of Lisbon's skyline, and to the labyrinth of trendy bars and restaurants in the narrow cobbled streets of the Bairro Alto, or upper town. The stone terraces on the Rua do Carmo that stopped the fire trucks will be ripped up and the street reopened to limited traffic. Mayor Sampaio said the Chiado project would set a precedent for restoring other parts of the city, some of which date to the 11th century. Two areas that need renovation are Alfama and Mouraria, where the rose-pink and ocher houses usually are in bad repair because regulated low rents do not leave the owners enough money to fix them. City housing expert Vasco Franco said 15 neglected houses collapsed in last winter's heavy rains and he hoped foreign financing could be obtained, perhaps from the European Community. Repairing the old houses is cheaper than building new ones, he said. Last year, the EC gave $135,000 toward the renovation of Mouraria, the old Arab quarter. ``Symbolic, but a good start,'' said Joao Geraldes, another city project coordinator.

DOC.HEAD: Witness, Victim, Symbol: The Jogger Survives
With AM-Central Park Jogger, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: She arrived in Central Park just another anonymous New York runner. She came out of a coma 15 days later as a tabloid headline, a victim of unspeakable crime, and a symbol of hope in a city choked by violence. She's known to millions now, but still maintains her anonymity; to all but a handful, she is as nameless and faceless as she was on April 19, 1989. Her remarkable recovery inspired the city, just as the brutality of her assault had horrified it. The Central Park jogger. She was found lying in a puddle of mud and blood early on April 20, unconscious. She arrived at Metropolitan Hospital a short time later, an unlikely candidate for survival, much less recovery. She seemed destined to become another fatality in a record year for homicides. Her skull had been fractured. Three-quarters of her blood was gone, splattered around the roadway crossing the park. Her body temperature had dipped into the 80s. She needed a machine to breathe. Her body was bruised literally from head to toe, with severe head lacerations, brain contusions and fractured facial bones. Photos of her injuries produced looks of dismay and disbelief from a jury which sat poker-faced through six weeks of graphic testimony about her injuries. On a scale of 3 to 15 used by neurologists to measure brain function, the woman was rated a 4. Even as she began to emerge from the coma, attending physician Dr. Howard S. Kurtz put her chances for full recovery at slim. Slowly, steadily, she came back. New Yorkers were cheered by reports of her high-fiving a nurse, of a soft ``hello'' to her brother. She had no recollection of the events that changed her life; her last memory before the attack was canceling dinner with a friend, her next was waking up in the hospital for the Memorial Day weekend. Her progress could be charted by the holidays: rapid improvement in a Connecticut rehabilitation center by Labor Day. Back home _ and out jogging again _ for Thanksgiving. Back at work by Christmas. And ringing in the new year with a promotion to vice president at Salomon Brothers. While it appeared on the surface that her life was returning to normal, the jogger _ in a dramatic, 12-minute appearance in a Manhattan courtroom _ demonstrated that things were forever altered in her life. It was 15 months after the attack when a bailiff in state Supreme Court summoned the woman, now 30, to the witness stand. By now, everyone knew who she was. There was silence for 2{ minutes as spectators and reporters waited, tension building, for the arrival of the Central Park jogger. She took her seat slowly, assisted by a court officer. A jagged scar ran along her face, mute testimony to the viciousness of her attackers. In a steady voice, she detailed the lasting effects of the beating she can't remember. ``I have problems with balance when I'm walking, and coordination. At times, I'll veer off to the right or the left,'' she testified. ``I have trouble walking down steps. I also lost my sense of smell completely. That has not come back. ``I have double vision. When I'm reading, I hold newspapers over to the left to compensate. It takes a fair amount of concentration to make the image one.'' She left the courtroom and slipped quietly back into her day-to-day existence, her anonymity respected by almost all news media. Yet everyone reported intimate details of the woman's life after her testimony: her method of birth control, the last time she made love with her boyfriend. A defense lawyer, in his closing argument, suggested she stopped for a tryst on her way to the park and had never been raped. Much of her background is well known: a Pennsylvania native, holder of graduate degrees from Yale, a Wall Street investment banker, a hard worker, a dedicated runner. Family members say she holds no grudges, and remains determined in her recovery. But no one can say what the future holds for the Central Park jogger, other than to say it can't be like the past. ``The fact that she could even come to this courtroom is a miracle,'' Assistant District Attorney Elizabeth Lederer told the jury in her closing argument. ``(The jogger) will never be the same as she was.''

DOC.HEAD: American Legion to Meet in Indianapolis
DOC.TEXT: Up to 25,000 old warriors will gather this week for the 72nd American Legion national convention, while their active-duty counterparts prepare for the possibility of combat in the Middle East. Beginning Friday, members of the nation's largest and most vocal war veterans organization gather in the city of their national headquarters. It is the first time that the 3 million-member Legion, founded in 1919, has held its annual meeting here. ``We call this our homecoming,'' said Lew Wood, the Legion's national director of public relations. ``We plan to have an old-fashioned, patriotic celebration, and most events will be held on our own front lawn.'' Unless events in the Middle East disrupt speakers' schedules, the week-long program is to include addresses by Army Gen. Colin L. Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff; retired Adm. Elmo R. Zumwalt, former chief of naval operations; and retired Air Force Brig. Gen. Chuck Yeager, the famed test pilot. The 3,400 delegates will vote on resolutions asking Congress to amend the American Legion's charter to permit veterans who served during recent actions in Grenada, Panama and Lebanon to join the organization. Under current rules, only those who served during World War I, World War II and the Korean and Vietnam wars may join. The convention will end Aug. 30.

DOC.HEAD: US Misread the Iraqis for Years
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: As military tensions in the Persian Gulf increase, the six-year American effort to moderate Iraqi policies seems in retrospect like perhaps the most ineffectual U.S. diplomatic venture in more than a decade. The Reagan administration's attempts to tame President Saddam Hussein evoke memories of the 1970s, when the United States tried to encourage peaceful behavior in the Soviet Union by promoting expanded trade and financial ties. Over the short term, the ``detente'' policy toward the Soviets was a disappointment. By contrast, it was a glittering success next to the outcome of the U.S. effort in Iraq. An overture to Iraq seemed to some an obvious option for the Reagan administration in the early 1980s. At the time, the big concern was Iran and its goal of spreading its Shiite fundamentalist orthodoxy elsewhere in the gulf region and beyond. By the fall of 1984, the United States had removed Iraq from the list of countries engaged in state-sponsored terrorism and had restored full diplomatic relations with Baghdad. American rice and wheat farmers began doing a flourishing business with Baghdad, and Iraq also made use of the U.S. Export-Import Bank to buy American products on credit. Overall transactions between the two countries were measured in the billions of dollars. The New York Times reported last week that the CIA provided the Iraqis with valuable military information on their Iranian foes the long and bloody Iran-Iraq war of the 1980s. The United States also helped finance Iraq's war effort through oil purchases. Part of the reason for helping the Iraqis was concern that they might otherwise be routed by Iran. Since the end of the war in 1988, the rationale for maintaining ties with Iraq changed: it was thought that Saddam would be eager to preserve the benefits of his economic ties with the United States and shape his foreign policy accordingly. Thus, the administration resisted congressional attempts this year to impose economic sanctions against Iraq, arguing that the dissolution of the relationship would rob the United States of all leverage with Saddam. So appalling was Iraq's behavior even before the Kuwaiti invasion that at least one farm state senator, Kansas Republican Nancy Kassebaum, lobbied hard for economic sanctions even though many of her own constituents have benefitted from Iraqi wheat purchases. The Iraqi conquest of Kuwait on Aug. 2 dramatized just how much the administration overestimated its sway with the Iraqis. To many members of Congress, the warning signs have been there to see for years. Iraq has a record of using chemical weapons dating back to 1984 and used them against Iraqi Kurds just two years ago. Since Iraq's war with Iran ended, there has been no appreciable reduction in Iraqi military spending. Iraq has a million-man military and missiles capable of reaching Israel. It is believed to be the world's largest manufacturer of chemical weapons. It may also be developing biological weapons and it is harboring some of the most radical Palestinian leaders. Secretary of State James A. Baker III spoke for many current and past government officials last week when, alluding to Iraq's behavior dating back to the 1980s, he said the United States ``should have been concerned about all of this'' years ago. Other officials conceded that the United States should have been far more outspoken in calling attention to Iraqi behavior. Perhaps Kuwait should have been more wary as well. The Kuwaitis lent the Iraqis more than $10 billion to help the finance Saddam's war effort against Iran. Now Saddam has contrived a way not to have to pay the Kuwaitis back.
