DOC.HEAD: Serbs Vote On Autonomy in Croatia
DOC.TEXT: Armed Serbs patrolled streets in the republic of Croatia Sunday to stop police from intervening as the Serb minority voted on autonomy in open defiance of a government ban. Voters formed long lines in front of polling booths in this Serbian center in southwestern Croatia for the referendum, organized by the Serbian Democratic Party. The party favors a degree of self-government for Serbs. Croatians, who are Roman Catholic, dominate the western half of Yugoslavia, while Orthodox Serbs form the majority in the south of the country. The two ethnic groups have been traditional rivals ever since they were united within Yugoslavia in 1918. According to official statistics, Serbs make up 11 percent of Croatia's 5 million people. The two ethnic groups are intermingled in a patchwork of small communities in southwestern Croatia. If the referendum is passed it is likely to worsen tensions between the two groups. Voting was to continue for the next two weeks in ethnic Serbian areas of Croatia. The vote was declared illegal by Croatia's government, which says it is part of a scenario to destabilize the newly elected administration. Organizers of the referendum said that all ethnic Serbs born in the area were being allowed to vote, and that the referendum is expected to be passed by a near unanimous vote. Nikola Ozegovic, the official in charge of one polling station, claimed that about 90 percent of the eligible voters among Knin's 10,000 Serbs had cast ballots by early afternoon. The town has a total population of about 11,000. He said that Croatians who expressed a desire to vote for autonomy were being allowed to participate in the ballot. He said two such Croatian women were permitted to vote at his polling station. Serbs armed with automatic rifles patrolled streets and stood guard at government buildings and the radio station to prevent police from intervening in the vote. On Friday and Saturday, armed villagers blocked highways leading to the Adriatic coast. On Sunday, traffic was reported to be flowing through the roadbocks, which were manned by Serbs with walkie-talkies. ``We can't believe the Serbs are suddenly so full of hatred for us,'' said Nikola Pozar, a local Croatian political leader. ``But we've been advised by the Croatian government not to respond to their provocations,'' he added. Authorities in Croatia, where a center-right party swept into power last spring in the first multiparty elections in the area in more than 50 years, claimed the plebiscite was being directed by the Communist leadership of Serbia, Yugoslavia's largest state. They said the effort was an attempt to divert public attention from the lack of democratic reforms in Serbia. Polling stations were decorated with posters showing the red, blue and white Serbian flag and a large ``Yes'' printed in the middle. There were no voting booths and ballots were marked openly in front of polling officials. Yugoslavia is a loose federation of six republics and two autonomous provinces.

DOC.HEAD: Commerce Secretary Says Growing Export Base Will Stem Recession
DOC.TEXT: Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher expects growing exports to keep the U.S. economy out of a recession this year. Reacting ecstatically to the record export posting in the latest merchandise trade report, Mosbacher said in an interview in his fifth floor office late last week: ``I feel that the export side ... not only will keep us out of recession but it's going to bring back a continuing higher growth.'' The record $34.3 billion in exports, combined with a reduced $39.37 billion in imports, resulted in a $5.07 billion trade deficit in June, the lowest since a $3.96 billion imbalance in June 1983. Asked if he were satisfied with the report, Mosbacher replied: ``Satisfied might be an understatement. I'm very pleased with it,'' he said, emphasizing the word ``very.'' So far this year, he said of the export gain, ``It's very much across the board _ it's capital goods, it's high-tech goods, and it's agriculture.'' The secretary repeated his belief that the nation's merchandise trade deficit would drop below $100 billion this year for the first time since 1983. Already, he said, the deficit has tumbled to $45.8 billion _ the lowest six-month imbalance since the second half of 1983. But like most other observers, he had a caveat _ the rising cost of oil following the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. ``Now you tell me how long the crisis will last and the prices will stay up? If the price of oil doesn't stay up very long, we'll still make it,'' he said. Many analysts have said they believe skyrocketing oil prices will cause America's oil bill to shoot up in the second half of the year, offsetting any growth in exports. Mosbacher said the United States has been running an oil deficit of between $47 billion and $48 billion a year _ ``That's $18 (a barrel) oil, plus or minus. If you've got $27 oil, you got about a 50 percent increase.'' On Friday, oil was costing nearly twice the $14.64 a barrel it averaged during June. Nevertheless, assuming oil prices do decline soon, he said, ``we're headed at close to a $90 billion trade deficit this year _ it could be $95 billion, under $100 billion is what I've been saying.'' That would be more than a one-third cut from the 1987 peak deficit of $152.12 billion. The trade imbalance has declined each year since then, falling to $109 billion last year. The commerce secretary attributed the export progress to the decline in the dollar, improved quality of U.S. goods and greater export expertise. ``U.S. goods are a lot cheaper overseas now for these customers,'' he said. `` Plus, our quality keeps improving and our knowledge of how to export ... keeps improving. And finally, the government's working with exporters....'' ``This is just what we need to accomplish to keep our competitive edge in this world _ export buildup,'' he said. ``You know, instead of talking about what we can do to limit imports, we need to keep working on building exports.'' Thus far, he said, the growing export base ``shows American business is competitive around the world, it shows American business is beginning to realize it's a global marketplace, with the biggest potential area of growth and unsatisfied demand is outside the U.S. ``And it does create jobs and business opportunities for everyone,'' he said. ``It can keep the economy on the positive side. I mean, keep us from ... a recession.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush Returns To Washington For Persian Gulf Briefing
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Bush scheduled to depart Kennebunkport at 3:30 p.m. EDT and arrive White House at 5:30 p.m. EDT
DOC.TEXT: A grim-faced President Bush headed back to Washington to review the Persian Gulf crisis with national security advisers Sunday as the administration for the first time called foreigners trapped in Iraq and Kuwait hostages. Bush scheduled a dinner meeting with senior officials and planned to remain at the White House overnight. On Monday, he will deliver a major speech in Baltimore before the annual Veterans of Foreign Wars convention, focusing on the showdown with Iraq and the high stakes it holds for the United States. The president is to return to his vacation home later Monday after stopping at a Republican fund-raising reception at a Rhode Island country club. Bush's mood has noticeably darkened over the past week as Baghdad has issued increasingly bellicose statements and has warned that it will use foreigners as a shield against Western attack. There are an estimated 3,000 Americans in Iraq and Iraqi-occupied Kuwait. Thomas R. Pickering, the U.S. ambassador to the United Nations, said Saturday that Iraqi President Saddam Hussein had made clear that ``he was going to hold hostage all foreigners.'' U.S. officials previously had avoided using the word ``hostage'' to describe the foreigners trapped since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. Bush, emerging from services at St. Ann's Episcopal Church with his family, ignored a reporter's shouted question about whether he agreed with Pickering's characterization. He walked directly to his limousine instead of stopping to greet fellow worshippers, as he usually does. A day earlier, a visibly irritated Bush announced that he was going to stop answering questions from reporters on the golf course. During Sunday's service, the rector, the Rev. Laman H. Bruner Jr., offered a poignant prayer for the president, the captive foreigners in Iraq and Kuwait and the success of the U.S. military mission. ``O, Almighty God, uphold the hand of our president in our resolve in the Middle East. Support with Thy might our people in their proving; that they fear not the threatenings and strokes of their enemy,'' Bruner said. ``Protect those who are interned and restore them to their homes in safety,'' he added.

DOC.HEAD: Closed Society, Heat Make Reporting Difficult in Saudi Arabia
DOC.TEXT: Western reporters are finding that the challenge of reporting in a society that has been virtually closed to foreigners until now is as stiff as working in heat that often soars above 100 degrees. Although the Saudi government allowed the Defense Department to chaperone a small pool of reporters in the country more than a week ago, it was not until the last few days that the kingdom agreed to grant visas for open coverage to more than a dozen journalists. When the thumbs-up came on visas, the networks were ready. ``We are hitting the ground running,'' NBC-TV's ``Today'' show co-host Bryant Gumbel said as he plotted the day's work Sunday with two producers in the coffee shop of the Dhahran International Hotel. Gumbel and at least a score of other foreign television and news reporters have arrived in Saudi Arabia, more than two weeks after Iraqi troops invaded Kuwait. The thousands of American troops President Bush dispatched to defend this desert kingdom have turned Saudi Arabia into the hottest news story around _ literally. Habib Shaheen, a spokesman for the Saudi government, said the number of reporters in the country was unprecedented. The last time he dealt with all four television networks here was three years ago when Iranians attacked Mecca, he said. On Saturday, the Saudi government flew reporters _ including some of the biggest names in television _ to Jiddah, 1,000 miles away, for interviews with top officials. Ever sensitive to the draw of television, the government arranged for NBC's Tom Brokaw, ABC's Sam Donaldson and CBS' Bob Simon to have individual interviews with the Saudi oil minister and the foreign minister. ``Very smooth,'' Donaldson pronounced after his 10 minutes with Prince Saud al-Faisal, the foreign minister. Al-Faisal, clad in his traditional flowing robe and red headdress, spoke in flawless English as he recounted Saudi Arabia's insistence that Iraqi troops leave Kuwait. The Saudis' decision to open their borders awed some reporters who until now have spent years trying to penetrate the kingdom. ``We would wait forever just to get one interview and now we have three top officials in one day,'' said Barnie Mason of BBC radio. Although the Saudis appear to be amenable to open coverage, Gumbel said he thought it might be difficult to really find out what is happening in the country, where some citizens are not keen on opening their society. ``We have a different culture; please be kind to us,'' said Ahmad Al-Otiri, an F-15 pilot. He said he hated television reports that seemed to be critical of Saudi Arabia, such as one that focused on Saudi displeasure at American soldiers wearing tee-shirts. And a high-ranking Saudi official said the reluctance for publicity ``has not been forgotten.'' Whatever the news, the logistics for covering it are formidable. CNN's Carl Rochelle was the pool reporter who flew to Saudi Arabia with the Defense Department. Once in the country, he and his technicians had to set up a portable satellite Earth station at the Dhahran Air Base. The heat was so intense that one technician was overcome and military officials were forced to install an air conditioner in a tent. ``We've learned to drink a lot of water,'' said Tom Mote, a CNN cameraman.

DOC.TEXT: Here are the 10 auto safety true-and-false questions included in this year's poll of drivers sponsored by a subsidiary of Ashland Oil Co. If a traffic light changes from green to yellow, you should hurry through the intersection. 2. If a car approaches you with its high beams on, it is recommended that you flash your high beams. 3. When you turn on your windshield wipers, you should also turn on your headlights. 4. If your brakes fail to work, the first thing you should do is use your car's emergency brake. 5. If your accelerator is stuck, you should immediately turn off the car's ignition. 6. Traffic accidents are primarily due to mechanical failures in cars. 7. Most deaths due to traffic accidents occur at night. 8. Most deaths due to traffic accidents occur in rural areas. 9. The answers: 1. False; 2. False; 3. True; 4. False; 5. False; 6. False; 7. True; 8. True; 9. True; 10 False.

DOC.HEAD: Defendants Guilty of Rape, Assault In Jogger Trial
DOC.TEXT: Jurors say they decided to acquit three teen-agers of attempted murder in the Central Park jogger case because they did not think the youths intended to kill the young woman, who suffered brain damage. Juror Rafael Miranda said the mood in the jury room was often tense, with ``a lot of screaming, and a lot of names called,'' before the teen-agers were convicted Saturday night of raping and assaulting the jogger. The anonymous victim, now 30, became a national figure as she recovered from the savage assault by a youth gang during her nightly run on April 19, 1989. The savage attack on the woman taking her nightly run horrified New Yorkers because of its randomness and brutality. After therapy, she returned to work and to jogging within eight months. But she doesn't remember the attack, has lost her sense of smell and sometimes has difficulty in walking and in focusing her vision. Like some other recent high-profile trials in New York City, this case involved victims and attackers of different races _ the three on trial were black or Hispanic and the victim was a white Wall Street executive. Supporters of the youths charged that the police were satisfied with the arrest of any minority suspect. Defense lawyers charged the defendants' incriminating statements were the product of police lies and intimidation. But Miranda said the jury of four blacks, four whites, three Hispanics and one Asian never was split along racial lines during 10 days of deliberations. The defendants _ Yusef Salaam, Antron McCray and Raymond Santana _ were acquitted of the top count of attempted murder and a lesser count of sodomy. Salaam, 16, McCray, 16, and Santana, 15, were tried as adults but will be sentenced as juvenile offenders on Sept. 11. They face up to five to 10 years in prison on the top count of rape. All three defense attorneys promised to appeal. Justice Thomas Galligan ordered them all jailed without bail. Three other defendants have yet to stand trial. The defendants' supporters demonstrated frequently outside the courthouse, accusing the victim of promiscuity and questioning her reasons for being in the park late at night. When prosecutor Elizabeth Lederer left the courthouse, a group shouted: ``The devil herself. The devil, she's going to pay for it.'' Lederer's boss, Manhattan District Attorney Robert Morgenthau, denied any racial element in the case. ``This city is ill-served by those who have sought to exploit it ... and advance their own private agendas,'' he said. ``The brutal events which occurred at Central Park late one April night in 1989 seared the soul of every decent New Yorker,'' Mayor David Dinkins said in a statement. ``We should recommit ourselves to building a city and forging a society in which such heinous crimes do not occur.'' Charles Nestorick, one of two jurors who agreed to talk with reporters after the verdict was read, said the attempted murder charges ``gave us a lot of difficulty because she had really been beaten.'' But he said the jurors felt the teens didn't realize how badly they had hurt her. ``Youths that age are not well versed in how many blows it takes to kill someone,'' he said. After three days of deliberating on nothing but the attempted murder charges, ``we saw that we couldn't prove intent,'' he said. Asked why it took 10 days for a verdict, Nestorick said one person held out to acquit McCray on rape and assault. The defendants' statements to police were the heart of the prosecution's case. A detective testified that Santana told him he counted 33 youths who entered the park to ``wild some joggers ... beat up and rip off joggers and cyclists.'' The defendants told detectives the naked woman was struck with a metal pipe, bashed in the head and face with a brick, cut on the legs with a knife and sexually attacked, Lederer said. The defendants also were convicted of first-degree riot; of assault and robbery in an attack on one male jogger and of assaulting a second man.

DOC.HEAD: Chiles' Renewed Use of Anti-depressant Dogs Gubernatorial Campaign
LaserPhoto NY7
DOC.TEXT: Former three-term Sen. Lawton Chiles is being chased by questions about his health, particularly his resumed use of the anti-depressant drug Prozac, as he heads into the stretch of the Democratic gubernatorial race. Since his surprise entry into the race in April, Chiles has been the front-runner both to win the Sept. 4 primary and to unseat Republican Gov. Bob Martinez in November. But an initial lead of 30 to 40 points over six-term U.S. Rep. Bill Nelson was down to 12 points in polls last month. And last month, Chiles disclosed that he had resumed taking Prozac. His use of the anti-depressant was leaked to the news media as he entered the race, but Chiles had stopped taking it until recently. ``I started experiencing some of the symptoms I'd seen before, so I resumed the taking of it,'' Chiles said Friday, citing loss of appetite and sleeplessness. ``They're doing much better now,'' he added. Nelson's running mate, state House Speaker Tom Gustafson, suggested two weeks ago Chiles could be a suicide risk in the governor's mansion. Nelson distanced himself from the remark and Gustafson eventually apologized. Questions about Chiles' use of Prozac come as the anti-depressant is the subject of lawsuits filed against its maker, Eli Lilly & Co. of Indianapolis, by users or their survivors linking the drug to violence and suicide. Eli Lilly says the drug has been prescribed to more than 2 million people and that extensive testing has shown no link to suicidal impulses. During the campaign's first live television debate Thursday, Nelson, 47, renewed his call for Chiles to release his medical records. Chiles agreed and said Friday he has told his physician to assemble his medical files. The 60-year-old Chiles, who underwent quadruple-bypass heart surgery in 1985, had balked at releasing records. But he decided to release them in hopes of quieting any concerns about his health. Chiles said voters don't query him about his health while he is out campaigning. ``I think they sort of look at me, see the schedule I'm keeping, and see how I'm doing,'' he said. With former U.S. Rep. Kenneth ``Buddy'' MacKay as his running mate, Chiles has sought to make big-money politics the issue. He and MacKay have long been among the state's most respected politicians for integrity. They have raised nearly $2 million while imposing a $100 limit on contributions. Nelson has raised $5.8 million, and Martinez has been running ahead of the Democrats in funds. The Democratic campaign has gotten more heated in its final month, with Nelson raising ethics charges against Chiles, and Chiles criticizing Nelson for the politics of negativism and big money. While Chiles hopes voters will back him against what one of his ads terms ``the politics of the sewer,'' Nelson is pushing the health issue. He wrote Chiles on Friday asking a timetable for the release of Chiles' medical records, and campaign manager Jay Hakes said Nelson will bring the disclosure issue up in their next televised debate Friday, if Chiles still hasn't responded. Nelson and Martinez, both joggers, made their medical records public months ago. Hakes said Chiles' health is a legitimate, but ``delicate,'' issue. ``I don't think it's really going to be appropriate to discuss Prozac,' Hakes said, calling it too personal. But the Nelson campaign cites Chiles' own statement in December 1987 that he was retiring from the Senate because he was burned out. Nelson repeatedly talks about ``energy and vitality.'' Chiles said he didn't recognize his depression until after he left the Senate. He decided to retire when, as Senate budget chairman, he became frustrated because Senate politics were making it impossible to make headway toward reducing the federal deficit. J.M. ``Mac'' Stipanovich, Martinez's sharp-tongued politic guru, said he would have no reticence in highlighting Chiles' mental health. ``Lawton Chiles by his own admission was incapable of continuing in public office,'' he said. ``By his own admission, he suffered from clinical depression. By his own admission, while campaigning without the medication, he couldn't sleep or function.'' Stipanovich said those admissions raise questions about how depressed Chiles is. ``They're all fair questions, and that has nothing to do with the morality of Prozac or depression,'' said Stipanovich, who said his own mother takes Prozac. ``That doesn't make him a bad person.'' Chiles insisted he's not worried, that he is proving he's fit. ``I'm sure they'll use anything against me,'' he said, chuckling.

DOC.HEAD: NAACP, Other Groups To Fight Social Problems
DOC.TEXT: The NAACP and more than 100 other organizations ranging from law enforcement to religious groups have formed a coalition to battle nagging social ills in black communities. The group, calling itself the National Association of Black Organizations, grew out of a three-day ``Summit Conference of Black Organizations'' in Washington assembled by the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People. Coalition members, which include groups as varied as the National Organization of Black Law Enforcement Executives and the Progressive National Baptist Convention, will focus their efforts on such problems as teen-age pregnancy, school dropouts and other social problems. NAACP Executive Director Benjamin Hooks said the coalition is designed to enhance the ``continuing struggle of African Americans to gain a fair share of the American dream.'' The organization's plans call for establishment of a communications network to share information, development of a brain trust to research and make recommendations on social and economic concerns affecting blacks, spreading of effective self-help initiatives, and development of strategies to strengthen support for black institutions. The NAACP moves in a new direction with the formation of the coalition. The nation's preeminent civil rights organization has traditionally focused on legislation and litigation. ``What we have accomplished here is but a beginning,'' Hooks said. ``It marks the start of a new approach, where the visible payoff is farther down the road.'' Hooks said the NAACP does not intend to turn from its historical focus. But he said the 81-year-old group also realizes the need for black organizations to address problems facing blacks. ``We as black people are stepping up to the bat and saying we are taking responsibility for our own destiny,'' Hooks said. He said the coalition's nine-member executive committee would meet within two weeks to work out further details. The conference concluded Saturday.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: The award-winning rhythm and blues group Soul II Soul canceled its North America tour after becoming involved in a seven-car pileup over the weekend. Jazzie B. _ the 27-year-old lead singer and songwriter whose real name is Beresford Romeo _ suffered back injuries, and doctors advisde him against performing for about a week, said the group's manager, Don Taylor. Four other band members were treated for minor injuries and released, Taylor said. He said the group canceled the rest of the shows on its itinerary, including performances in the west Chicago suburb of Hoffman Estates; Columbus, Ohio; Montreal; Toronto; Bristol, Conn.; and Boston. The group's two tour buses were involved in a chain-reaction accident Saturday that sent 31 people to three hospitals, Illinois State Trooper Bruce Shimizu said. In February, the band won a Grammy award in the rhythm and blues category for the ``Back to Life'' single. Their song ``African Dance'' was named best instrumental.

Comedian Yakov Smirnoff's success brought him from a one-room apartment in Moscow to a five-bedroom house near the glittering Sunset Strip. But with the birth of his first child approaching, he's giving up his trendy address for a quieter, family oriented neighborhood ``We want a better place for Linda to push the baby cart,'' Smirnoff said in a recent interview after returning Los Angeles following appearances in Las Vegas and Atlantic City, N.J. The former Soviet citizen and his wife, Linda, are purchasing the 3,500-square-foot home on the 18th hole of the Riviera Country Club for $2.4 million and listing their old one for about $1.8 million. The new home, in the Pacific Palisades area of Los Angeles, has three bedrooms and a maid's quarters. ``It's something like a Mr. and Mrs. Cleaver house. And it's one-story, which will be better for our child,'' said Smirnoff, who moved to the United States 13 years ago and became a citizen in 1986. Goldie Hawn and Tom Hanks will be among the Smirnoffs' new neighbors. Smirnoff appeared with Hanks in the movie ``The Money Pit'' and with fellow comedian Robin Williams in ``Moscow on the Hudson.''

Pop superstar Michael Jackson invited 130 children to his ranch, where the YMCA day campers from Santa Barbara and Los Angeles visited his zoo, video arcade and custom theater. At first, the children, age 7 to 13, were in awe of Michael Jackson, but that quickly changed. ``He was so much more than I expected. I thought he was going to say `hi' and `bye.' But he played with us the whole time,'' said 12-year-old Monique Jackson of Los Angeles. During Saturday's visit, the kids presented the star with a banner that said ``We love you Michael,'' and made him an honorary member of the 28th Street YMCA in Los Angeles, said Lee Solters, a Jackson spokesman. Jackson has invited groups of children to his mountain estate before. Last month, he spontaneously asked a group of terminally ill children who were camping nearby to come for a barbecue and movie.

Former Colorado Sen. Gary Hart is using his experience in politics to capitalize on the newly democratizing East bloc. Three years after dropping out of the presidential race, the 53-year-old Democrat is helping a newly incorporated consulting practice at a Denver law firm to assist U.S. companies expand into foreign markets. Hart says he's not from the same mold as former Secretary of State Henry Kissinger. ``I'm not a jet-setter or a Kissinger,'' he said. ``I never thought of public service as a career and always knew I'd come back to the private sector. My activities aren't just based on old friends.'' Hart also has expanded outside the East bloc, helping the Italian state energy company ENI explore oil and gas acquisitions in the United States. He also represented a Taiwanese group of 27 companies looking for hotels.

DOC.HEAD: Key Dates In Case of Central Park Jogger
With AM-Central Park Jogger Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A chronology of key dates in the Central Park jogger case:

April 19 _ The female jogger, out for an evening run, is brutally attacked, raped and left for dead in Central Park. April 20 _ The badly battered woman, comatose and suffering from hypothermia, is discovered and rushed to Metropolitan Hospital. Her prognosis for recovery is pessimistic. Police say a gang of teen-agers out for a night of ``wilding'' was responsible. April 23 _ Suspects are arraigned. A prosecutor says seven of eight suspects made incriminating statements to police about the attack. April 26 _ Yusef Salaam and Raymond Santana are indicted on charges of rape and attempted murder. April 27 _ Kharey Wise, Antron McCray and Steven Lopez are indicted on charges of rape and attempted murder. Jermaine Robinson is indicted for attack on a male jogger in the park. Clarence Thomas, 14, released with no charges brought. April 28 _ Kevin Richardson is indicted on charges of rape and attempted murder. Parks Commissioner Henry Stern announces wide-ranging plans to improve Central Park security. May 1 _ Jogger's condition improves enough to give a nurse a ``high five.'' May 3 _ Jogger emerges from coma, whispers ``Hello'' to her brother. May 17 _ The jogger undergoes surgery to repair her shattered face. June 7 _ She is transferred to Gaylord Hospital in Wallingford, Conn., for physical and mental rehabilitation. Oct. 5 _ Jermaine Robinson, 15, pleads guilty to robbery in attack on a male jogger the same night of the rape-assault. Oct. 9 _ Genetic evidence tested by the FBI turns up no link to the half-dozen rape suspects. Nov. 14 _ The jogger is released from Gaylord Hospital after a ``miraculous'' recovery. Nov. 27 _ She returns to her job at Salomon Brothers on Wall Street.

Jan. 1 _ The jogger is promoted to a vice president at Salomon Brothers. Feb. 23 _ State Supreme Court Justice Thomas Galligan rules the suspects' statements to police the day of their arrests are admissible at trial. March 16 _ The case is split into two trials, with Antron McCray, Yusef Salaam and Raymond Santana the first three defendants to be tried. May 30 _ Michael Briscoe pleads guilty to separate attack on the night of the jogger rape. June 13 _ Jury selection begins. June 25 _ Opening arguments in the trial. July 16 _ The jogger, in a 12-minute appearance on the witness stand, details the lasting injuries of the attack: amnesia, lack of balance, no sense of smell. Aug. 1 _ Defendant Yusef Salaam, over the objection of two defense lawyers, takes the stand and declares his innocence. Aug. 6 _ Salaam's mother, Sharonne, is ejected from the courtroom after an outburst in which she calls one prosecutor a liar in the presence of the jury. Aug. 7 _ Defense closing arguments. Aug. 8 _ Prosecution closing. Aug. 9 _ Jury begins deliberating. Aug. 18 _ The three defendants are convicted of rape and assault and acquitted of the top count of attempted murder.

DOC.HEAD: Spokeswoman: No Release Date Discussed for Atwater
DOC.TEXT: Physicians treating Lee Atwater have not decided when to release the Republican National Committee chairman from the hospital, a spokeswoman said Sunday. ``There is no release date and ... I have heard no discussion of that,'' said Leslie Goodman, the RNC spokeswoman. Atwater has been undergoing radiation therapy at a Washington hospital since Wednesday for brain tumor ``progression.'' Published reports had indicated that physicians found a new tumor in the brain of the 39-year-old South Carolinian. But Goodman has said doctors were not specific about whether Atwater was afflicted with a new tumor or the recurrence of a previous one. Atwater, who gained prominence in national political circles when he directed President Bush's 1988 campaign, underwent brain tumor surgery on April 3. He has since been in and out of the hospital repeatedly for treatment of ailments ranging from a blood clot in his leg to a nagging fever. Atwater was described as alert and said to be receiving visitors following therapy. Goodman said Sunday that his condition was ``unchanged.''

DOC.HEAD: Future of Defense Personnel Cuts Clouded by Crisis in Persian Gulf
LaserPhoto NR1
DOC.TEXT: May of the civilian workers from Fort Monmouth crowding into Hannah's restaurant after work recently have been crying in their beer as well as quaffing it. The 292 employees laid off from the Army post were among some 5,400 at installations nationwide to receive pink slips in a continuing congressional effort to trim President Bush's proposed $307 billion defense budget. Fort Monmouth, with 8,200 civilian and 2,800 military workers, provides high-tech logistic support for military operations and has a research and development center for military electronics. The Army called the layoffs RIF terminations, for Reduction in Force. No matter what they're called, Carol Locklin, a Fort Monmouth secretary, will be out of work effective Oct. 15 unless the ``RIF'' is reversed. ``We don't really have savings, so to speak,'' said the 42-year-old Bricktown resident. ``It's going to really affect us if I don't find a job that pays as much money.'' Some members of the House and Senate Armed Services Committees have lobbied to shrink the defense forces, citing the budget deficit and democratization of Eastern Europe. The Senate Armed Services Committee wants to reduce the military force by 100,000, and the House Armed Services Committee wants it cut by 129,500, the Defense Department said. Some fort employees hope the invasion of Kuwait by Iraq and the projected deployment of as many as 250,000 military personnel to the Middle East will give both houses of Congress reason to reconsider proposed cutbacks. Bill Eastburn, a section chief in the fort's Computer Controlled Systems-Automatic Data Processing division, said an RIF notice he received in 1970 was retracted. ``I keep telling other people my experience,'' Eastburn said. ``I tell them, don't jump off a bridge. Just hang in there. Now, with the Iraqi situation, this may all be wiped out with a phone call or the stroke of a pen.'' Eastburn's optimism finds some echo in Congress. ``I think what's going on now will bring some appreciation to members of keeping a ready reserve and a ready capability,'' said Alabama Rep. William Dickinson, the ranking Republican on the House Armed Services Committee. ``We can't just slash defense spending and think everything will be OK. The world's just not like that.'' President Bush _ who had proposed cutting 37,605 troops in his 1991 budget request _ has cited the dispatch of U.S. forces and materiel to the Middle East in arguing against large-scale defense cuts. Because Congress has not decided how large the reduction in armed forces should be, no termination notices have been given to enlisted staff, said Maj. Doug Hart, a Pentagon public affairs officer. Through attrition, retirement and a cutback in recruitment, the number of troops in all branches of the service has fallen from 2.12 million to 2.05 million in the 12 months ending June 30. A hiring freeze mandated by Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney on Jan. 11 has helped shrink the civilian work force from 1.15 million at the end of 1989 to 1.13 million as of June 30, Hart said. Layoffs for the military's 1991 fiscal year, which begins Oct. 1, so far have exclusively affected Army civilians, he said. At Fort Monmouth, there had been talk of layoffs for weeks. But when the division chief called Mrs. Locklin to his office this month to say she would lose her $16,000-a-year job, she was shocked. The notification was dated Aug. 9. ``The worst I thought they would do is move me or downgrade me,'' Mrs. Locklin said. People at Fort Monmouth are running scared, Mrs. Locklin said. ``They're wondering, `Am I next?' '' she said. At Hannah's, manager Chuck Armstrong said the layoffs haven't translated into reduced business. ``Everyone comes over to party after they get their pink slips,'' said Armstrong, who keeps petitions to save Fort Monmouth jobs in the restaurant entrance.

DOC.HEAD: Tammy Bakker Appeals for Funds, Hopes for Flock From Disney
DOC.TEXT: Evangelist Tammy Faye Bakker held her first service in a converted warehouse near Disney World on Sunday after winning a zoning appeal to allow a religious congregation on the site. Mrs. Bakker told about 60 followers that she had the support of her imprisoned husband, Jim Bakker, and may consider moving services to Friday evening in order to draw additional people from the nearby theme park. The Orange County Commission last week reversed a zoning board decision that prohibited Mrs. Bakker from holding services in the industrial park where her ministry has its television recording studios. Attorneys for the American Civil Liberties Union representing Mrs. Bakker before the commission argued the ban was unconstitutional. ``I was in shock when we finally won it,'' she told worshippers Sunday. ``I guess I've kind of gotten used to accepting defeat.'' She pleaded for donations to meet the rent and other expenses. Her husband is in a federal prison in Minnesota, serving a 45-year term for bilking $3.7 million from followers of his former Praise the Lord ministry in South Carolina. The Bakkers set up an Orlando-based cable-television ministry before his conviction last year on fraud and conspiracy charges. Since then the ministry has been located in a shopping center, a former piano sales store and a hotel before moving to the International Corporate Park.

DOC.HEAD: Mauz To Head U.S. Forces In Middle East
DOC.TEXT: Pentagon officials on Sunday said Vice Adm. Henry H. Mauz Jr., commander of the Navy's 7th Fleet, has assumed duties as commander of U.S. Naval Forces, Central Command, in the Middle East. In the new post Mauz will direct the ``maritime intercept force'' poised to enforce United Nations sanctions against Iraq, the Pentagon said in a statement issued in the name of Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney, who was traveling in the Persian Gulf area. The United States is pouring thousands of soldiers into Saudi Arabia to protect its largest source of foreign oil from a possible Iraqi attack. Iraq overran Kuwait Aug. 2 and annexed the emirate six days later. U.S. officials have said the troop deployment could reach 200,000 men and women. The Pentagon said Mauz will retain his responsibilities as commander of the 7th Fleet, based in Japan. He has held that post since October 1988.

DOC.HEAD: Sudanese Ferry Turned Back, Chinese Freighter Searched
DOC.TEXT: U.S. warships forced an empty Sudanese ferry to turn back and searched a Chinese freighter Sunday before allowing it to proceed to this Jordanian port, a port official said. At the Pentagon, Defense Department officials confirmed that the USS Scott, a destroyer, turned back a Cypriot ferry flying the flag of Sudan as it attempted to enter Aqaba. The Jordanian official said the ferry, identified the Dongola, was on its way to Aqaba to pick up 550 Sudanese waiting to be ferried home after crossing into Jordan from Iraq and Kuwait late last week. He could not be named under regulations. But a Pentagon offical, who also could not be identified by name, said the commander of the Scott had determined that the Dongola also carried cargo banned under the U.N. sanctions against Iraq. The Pentagon official described the incident as ``amicable,'' and said that no shots were fired. In Khartoum, Sudanese Foreign Minister Ali Sahloul said he has ordered his ambassador in Washington to lodge a protest. He also said Sudan plans to protest to the United Nations. Sahloul said the Dongola had 200 tons of cargo, mainly steel, aboard. He said it was unloading at Port Sudan Thursday when it was urgently requested to go to Aqaba to pick up the Sudanese. He said the vessel was now anchored 110 miles off of Aqaba. Sudan's Justice Minister Ahmed Mahmoud Hassan called the U.S. interception ``illegal and a violation of human rights.'' ``The ship was on its way to evacuate civilians escaping a battle area,'' he said. The Jordanian port official said a Chinese-flagged freighter identified as the Chan Chin was also stopped and searched, but was allowed to proceed. He said the ship was on its way to Aqaba from the Saudi port of Jiddah. Aqaba, Jordan's only port, is used extensively as a transit point for Iraqi-bound cargo, which is unloaded there and transported overland by truck. Though Jordan has said it will abide by the U.N. sanctions against Iraq, it has yet to start implementing the resolution and Iraqi-bound shipments continue to be channeled through Aqaba. King Hussein has said Jordan wants to discuss the sanctions after consultations with the United Nations in view of Jordan's heavy dependence on trade with Iraq. The United States has said it will enforce the embargo against Baghdad by tightly controlling shipping to Iraq. The embargo was called by the United Nations following Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Vote On Whether to Put KGB Renegade into Parliament
DOC.TEXT: Voters considered Sunday whether to give a seat in the national parliament to a KGB renegade who says the Soviet secret police still play dirty tricks and cling to Stalinist repression. A total of 20 candidates were running against former KGB agent Oleg Kalugin for a seat in the Congress of People's Deputies from the southern Russian province of Krasnodar. Among them were cosmonaut Anatoly Berezovoi, a veteran of a 211-day space flight in 1982; and Gen. Vladimir Sein, political chief of the Transcaucasian Military District. Election commission officials in Krasnodar said nearly 60 percent of the 3.5 million eligible voters turned out to vote. The winner was expected to be announced Monday, although a runoff may be necessary. The KGB and its supporters tried hard to discredit Kalugin before the election. One resident of the region about 740 miles south of Moscow on the Black Sea wrote to the Arguments and Facts weekly that rumors were circulating that people who voted for Kalugin would be imprisoned. Kalugin worked as an operative in the United States from 1958-1970, first under the cover of a Radio Moscow correspondent and later as a first secretary in the Soviet Embassy in Washington. Kalugin's recent charges of wiretapping, smear campaigns and other dirty tricks have been a major thorn in the KGB's side while it is trying to improve its image. Many Soviets associate the KGB and its predecessor agencies with the deaths of millions of people under dictator Josef Stalin in the 1930s and 1940s and exile, beatings and imprisonment of dissidents through the early 1980s. Kalugin, 55, focused renewed attention on the KGB's tarnished past _ and he claims its present _ when he went public in June. He told foreign and Soviet journalists that KGB agents are still tapping telephones, infiltrating the Russian Orthodox Church and labor unions, and carrying out dirty tricks at the behest of their superiors. He said the agency should be abolished. At first, the KGB rejected his charges as hostile and distorted and accused him of making them to further his own political ambitions. Later, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev stripped his military rank and decorations for ``compromising the honor and dignity of the state security organs.'' The Soviet prosecutor then began investigating Kalugin under a law against divulging state secrets. Kalugin is fighting back with a lawsuit against Gorbachev, Premier Nikolai Ryzhkov and KGB chief Vladimir Kryuchkov. A member of the Democratic Platform reform movement, Kalugin is trying to gain a seat in the the national parliament that meets twice yearly. The seat became vacant in June when Ivan Polozov left to become the Communist Party chief of the Russian federation.

DOC.HEAD: All Quiet in Saudi Border Town, But Some Are Fearful
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of people who had fled this desert city near the Saudi-Kuwait border are returning because they believe the threat of attack by Iraq has eased. But some are still jittery. Khalid Al Otaishan, the administrative head of the area, said he had drawn up an evacuation plan that calls for 50,000 people to move to a tent city should Iraqi troops cross the border from Kuwait. ``We have warned the people,'' Al Otaishan said in an interview outside the city government building that overlooks the Persian Gulf. Six Saudi tanks could be seen parked in the desert several hundred yards away. The governor said more Saudi troops were stationed nearby, but few could be seen in the city, which resembled a ghost town in the midday sun. Handfuls of Saudi soldiers prayed along the side of the road during regular Moslem prayer times. Only one batch of American soldiers was spotted in the course of a day: seven Army men sat in a parked station wagon at the border checkpoint. One studied a detailed map of the area. ``I am sorry we can't talk to you,'' the colonel in charge told an American reporter. The Americans were among a force of tens of thousands of troops deployed to the Persian Gulf region, backed up by an array of planes and warships. Mursi Abu Bakr, whose family owns the Al Khafji Hotel, was asked if he was worried about an invasion. ``The first week we were. Now things are getting better and we work the best we can,'' he said. The arrival of American and other troops in the region provided somewhat of a sense of security, he said. But Scott Scheid of Newport Beach, Calif., said the town, only six miles from the border checkpoint, was too close for comfort to occupied Kuwait, with its huge Iraqi military contingent. ``I don't think you want to be here if something starts up,'' said Scheid, who works for an American oil company is based in Khobar, more than 180 miles to the south. His company has evacuated its 19 local employees from Khafji. ``There is a lot of tension in the air,'' said Scheid's co-worker, Albert Skiba of Tuscon, Ariz. Khafji was flooded with Kuwaiti refugees after the invasion. ``For the first week, it was terrible,'' Al Otaishan said. ``They needed too much food, water.'' The small oil town continues to serve as a magnet for those who flee across the desert from Kuwait, as well as for those awaiting word from relatives and friends still in Kuwait. Iraq annexed the emirate six days after the invasion, and Baghdad has said Kuwait is now irrevocably part of Iraq.

DOC.HEAD: Huge Roadside Yard Sale Provides Miles of Bargains
DOC.TEXT: For anyone into yard sales, it was hand-me-down heaven _ the U.S. 127 Corridor 450-Mile Outdoor Sale Festival. Sunday marked the end of the fourth annual, four-day, four-state roadside extravaganza, which started Thursday. It stretched from Covington, Ky., and ended around Gadsden, Ala., passing through Tennessee and Georgia. Although there wasn't a continuous line of stalls along the entire route, there was no shortage of tables and truckbeds to pick over and racks to browse through. The festival is meant to help the economies of small towns and counties along U.S. 127 by luring tourists off the interstates. ``We've got beautiful scenery along 127 and it's worth the drive _ even if you don't find any bargains,'' said Judy Roysden of Jamestown, Tenn. She said the sale was promoted in tourist magazines and by tourism departments in Kentucky and Tennessee. Business slowed down toward the end the weekend after a brisk start on Thursday and Friday. Several dealers attributed the slump to travelers from northern states already having passed through. George and June Minor of Louisville, Ky., who were en route to the annual Pioneer Days Festival in Kentucky's Mercer County, said they didn't know about the yard sale event but were stopping at many of the stands. ``George is crazy about yard sales,'' June Minor said. By Saturday afternoon, some dealers were beginning to see travelers returning from the south, their vans and cars loaded and their pockets empty. Rebekka Seigel of Owenton, Ky., about 25 miles north of Frankfort, said a Pennsylvania man had stopped to buy some marbles but lacked the money to pay for them. ``His van was completely full,'' she said. The man pulled out a piece of pottery made in North Carolina and asked if the Seigels would trade. They did and the man added 100 marbles to his load. ``His van would have been a real treat to go through,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Iran Prepared to Ease Tensions With Iraq, Won't Violate Embargo
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: An Iranian newspaper close to the government said Sunday that Tehran is prepared to ease tensions with Iraq, but will not help Baghdad circumvent a multinational embargo. Iranian media also reported Sunday that the withdrawal of thousands of Iraqi troops from the Iraqi-Iranian border will be completed by Tuesday. Many of those troops are expected to be shifted to the Iraqi-Kuwait border, where they will face U.S. forces. The English-language Tehran Times, which is close to Iranian President Hashemi Rafsanjani, said Iraq demonstrated good will by offering Wednesday to bring a formal end to the 1980-1988 Iran-Iraq war. A cease-fire halted the fighting two years ago. The English-language daily said Tehran was ``well prepared to reciprocate any Iraqi goodwill gesture.'' But it denied suggestions that Iran would help Baghdad violate the economic sanctions imposed by the United Nations. The measures were enacted after Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. Iran has condemned the invasion. The daily said ``Western circles and U.S. congressional quarters'' were voicing such concerns ``to drag Iran into the current crisis.'' It also stressed that ``Iran will in no way pit itself in a war against Iraq in order for the Kuwaiti sheiks to return, or for the sake of Western interests in this part of the world.'' Iran's official Islamic Republic News Agency said Sunday the Iraqi troops blew up fortifications and laid minefields along the border as they withdrew. As the three-day-old pullout continued, the biggest prisoner-of-war exchange since World War II gathered momentum after Iraq began the long-delayed swap of soldiers captured in the Persian Gulf war. Iraq's army daily, al-Qaddisiyah, has reported that an unspecified number of the 30 divisions it said were deployed along the 730-mile frontier with Iran following the cease-fire will be sent south to confront U.S. forces in Saudi Arabia. The divisions contain an estimated total of about 300,000 troops. Iran's news agency quoted an unidentified Iranian officer as saying that since the pullback of forces began Friday, Iraq has withdrawn 90 percent of the forces that it had occupying an estimated 700 square miles of captured Iranian territory. The number of troops in that territory is unclear. The withdrawal is part of the peace initiative with Iran launched by Iraqi President Saddam Hussein last week, primarily aimed at securing his eastern flank in the confrontation with the United States. In the POW exchanges, IRNA said 3,000 men were repatriated by Iraq and 2,000 by Iran. The agency quoted an unidentified Foreign Ministry spokesman in Tehran as saying that the two countries have agreed to speed up the exchange from 2,000 men a day to 8,000. The Red Cross has registered some 50,000 POWs held by Iran and 30,000 held by Iraq. But United Nations officials and diplomats in the region estimate there are as many as 100,000 men held by both sides.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Marines Bring Hundreds of Foreigners Out of Liberia
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to UPDATE with 800 people evacuated. Pick up 7th graf pvs, `The Rev...'
DOC.TEXT: About 800 people, most of them Lebanese, were plucked from Liberia's war-ravaged capital Sunday by U.S. Marines and flown by helicopter to neighboring Sierra Leone. The helicopters were arriving so quickly at a heliport on the outskirts of Sierra Leone's capital of Freetown that there was chaos in the waiting room. The evacuees were first flown from Monrovia to U.S. warships off the West African coast and then ferried to Sierra Leone. More than 600 of the evacuees were Lebanese. The Lebanese Embassy had said earlier that about 670 of its nationals were expected to arrive in Sierra Leone on Sunday, and that two jets have been chartered to take them to Beirut on Tuesday and Wednesday. The three arms of the Red Cross movement in Sierra Leone _ the League of Red Cross, the Sierra Leone Red Cross Organization and the International Red Cross _ were helping care for the evacuees, who included Haitians, Togolese, Zaireans and Columbians. Others who had been expected to arrive Sunday included a few Americans, some Germans, French, Indians, Chinese and a Ghanaian priest. The Rev. Francis Johnson, whose Roman Catholic church was located on Monrovia's Bushrod Island, said the fighters of rebel leader Prince Johnson escorted him to the U.S. Embassy for the evacuation. The priest described the situation in Monrovia as ``horrible.'' ``Monrovia is dead, no activities, dead bodies lie all over the place, houses are burned down and warehouses are looted,'' he said. The priest appealed to all embassies, particularly those of Sierra Leone, Nigeria and Ghana, to evacuate their citizens from Liberia. ``These countries should do away with politics and diplomacy and see to the lives of their nationals,'' he said. It has been confirmed here that 1,300 Sierra Leoneans remain trapped in their country's embassy. Johnson said foreigners still trapped in Liberia were hoping that West African peacekeeping troops will arrive and halt the fighting. ``But the troops are too slow in coming,'' he said. Sources in Sierra Leone said there was still no indication when the peackeeping force would leave. Its deployment has been delayed while negotiators try to persuade rebel leader Charles Taylor to accept a cease-fire and cooperate with the force. President Samuel Doe and Taylor's rival, Johnson, have accepted.

DOC.HEAD: Strong Thunderstorms Develop In Upper Ohio Valley
DOC.TEXT: Locally heavy rain caused flooding Sunday in West Virginia and flooding caused by earlier rain threatened a dam in Indiana, forcing evacuations. Thunderstorms developed overnight along and south of a stationary front and produced heavy rain in the upper Ohio Valley, and developed over some of the same areas again Sunday afternoon, including eastern Kentucky, southern Ohio and southwestern West Virginia. Thunderstorms dumped more than 5 inches of rain on parts of northwestern West Virginia early Sunday, forcing people from their homes and leaving a couple clinging to a clump of trees after their pickup was washed away, authorities said. ``We got a call when a neighbor saw the truck floating away,'' said Wood County Sheriff's Sgt. Mark King. ``By the time our deputies got there, the water was over the truck.'' King said a number of homes along a creek were evacuated, many county roads were inaccessible because of downed trees, minor mud slides and high water, and there were power outages. Parkersburg received 3.4 inches of rain, while Clarksburg in nearby Harrison County received 2.6 inches. In northeastern Wood County, 5.1 inches of rain was measured in 3{ hours early Sunday. At Rochester, Ind., a hospital and apartments for elderly people were evacuated as a precaution Sunday when high water threatened to break a dam on Lake Manitou, police said. Six inches of rain Saturday pushed the lake about 2 feet above flood stage and leaks appeared in the dam. Officials said between 50 and 75 people were evacuated from the Waterhaven Apartments and another 28 were moved from the hospital. Volunteers, fire crews and civil defense officials laid about 13,000 sand bags along the dam early Sunday, Fulton County chief jailer Robert Bryant said. Showers and a few thunderstorms also extended from eastern South Dakota to Wisconsin during Sunday afternoon. Showers and thunderstorms also were scattered across Florida and the central Gulf Coast region, along the middle Atlantic Coast and southern New England, and over the lower Great Lakes. Elsewhere, isolated showers and thunderstorms were over central Arkansas, central Oklahoma and eastern Kansas. Isolated showers spread along and west of the central Rockies. During the night and early Sunday, showers and thunderstorms produced locally heavy rain in the southern Plains, the North Central states, the Great Lakes, the upper Ohio Valley and Florida. Heavier rainfall totals for the six hours up ,to 2 a.m. EDT included 1.9 inches at Grand Rapids, Mich., and 1.7 inches at Key West, Fla. Heavier rainfall for the six hours up to 8 a.m. EDT included 4.9 inches at Altus, Okla.; 2.8 inches at Rockford, Ill.; And 1.9 inches at Akron, Ohio. For the six hours up to 2 p.m. EDT, heavier rainfall included 3.1 inches at Islip, N.Y., and 1.8 inches at Rochester, Minn. Blustery north wind ushered cool air into New England during the afternoon. Afternoon readings were only in the 60s across much of the area from the northern Plains to New England, with temperatures in the 50s in some areas. Morning lows dipped into the upper 40s and 50s across parts of the northern Plains, the upper Mississippi Valley, the Great Lakes and the northern Atlantic Coast. Lows also were in the 40s and 50s in the Rocky mountain region and the Great Basin covering Nevada and western Utah. Sunday's low for the Lower 48 states was 35 at Gunnison, Colo.

DOC.HEAD: Saddam Demands U.S. Pullout, Embargo Halt, in Exchange For Detainees
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with French, Spanish reaction, reorganizes. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Iraq promised on Sunday to free citizens of nations that are neutral in the Persian Gulf crisis, but renewed threats to punish ``aggressive'' countries by using their nationals as a shield against attacks. Three thousand Americans are among about 21,000 Westerners who were trapped by Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. In a series of statements on Sunday, Baghdad promised to allow the nationals of five European countries to leave Iraq and occupied Kuwait, but said it would use the other trapped foreigners _ including Americans _ as protection against attacks on vital installations. ``Our people are seeking to avert a catastrophe,'' President Saddam Hussein said in comments read by an announcer on Iraqi television. ``The presence of the foreigners with Iraqi families at vital targets might prevent an attack.'' Saddam demanded the withdrawal of U.S. and other forces deployed to protect Saudi Arabia, and called for an end to the international embargo against Iraq. When those conditions were met, he said, all foreigners would be free to go. Iraq's treatment of the foreigners was denounced by Western governments. France said Sunday it had been informed by the Iraqis that 27 of its nationals in Iraq and Kuwait had been taken from their hotels to undisclosed locations. It protested the move and ordered its naval commanders in the Persian Gulf to firmly enforce the United Nations embargo. Spain's foreign minister, Francisco Fernandez Ordonez, called Saddam's threats ``absolutely unacceptable.'' There are 184 Spaniards in Iraq and Kuwait. Britain, which has about 4,000 citizens in Iraq and Kuwait, has accused Baghdad of using ``outlaw tactics'' in its treatment of foreigners. The White House on Saturday said Iraq's holding American and other foreign citizens is ``totally unacceptable,'' and denounced the use of ``innocent civilians as pawns.'' Late Saturday, the U.N. Security Council unanimously demanded that Iraq let all foreigners leave. Baghdad said Sunday it would allow citizens from five countries to leave Iraq and occupied Kuwait as a ``goodwill gesture'' _ because their governments had not sent ``aggressive forces'' to the region. The official Iraqi News Agency quoted Sadi Mehdi Saleh, the speaker of the Iraqi parliament, as saying Austrian, Swiss, Swedish, Finnish and Portuguese would be allowed to leave Iraq. Those nationals account for fewer than 600 of the stranded Westerners. They included 160 Swedes, 48 Finns, 140 Swiss, 140 Austrians and 100 Portugese. The news agency quoted Saleh as saying the National Council, or parliament, would consider allowing citizens of other countries neutral in the crisis to leave as well. Saddam, whose broadcast message was monitored in Nicosia, called on the U.N. Security Council to guarantee a withdrawal of U.S. and other Western forces from the region. He suggested Saudi Arabia be given assurances the Security Council would coordinate ``collective military action'' against Iraq if it attacked the kingdom. Under what the Iraqi agency described as Saddam's ``peace initiative,'' the Security Council also was to guarantee regional security ``on the basis...of our previous initiative.'' That was a reference to an earlier offer from Saddam, linking a possible withdrawal from Kuwait to Israel's withdrawal from occupied Arab territories and a Syrian withdrawal from Lebanon. Saddam said the Kuwait crisis ``should be left for Arabs to tackle as an Arab issue,'' and denounced the United States and Britain as the chief obstacles to peace. ``Let us cooperate to prevent these governments from committing major crimes ... which will result in an inferno and an insurmountable flood of fire,'' he said. He said the detention of foreigners was meant to prevent ``death, murder and starvation'' that he said would result from American policy. Thus, he said, holding the foreigners was ``a service to humanity.'' Earlier Sunday, Iraq ordered Westerners in three cities in occupied Kuwait to report to hotels in the Kuwaiti capital. He issued veiled threats against anyone who disobeyed. ``Anyone who does not comply will, together with his government, bear full responsibility for any undesirable action that might be targeted against them by hostile elements,'' said the news agency, monitored in Nicosia. It was the second such asssembly order in four days. On Thursday, American and British nationals in Kuwait were ordered to report to hotels, but no Iraqi officials were there to meet the few who showed up. Britain's Foreign Office said it was told by the Iraqis that those who report to the hotels would be taken to ``key installations in Kuwait and Iraq'' while those who did not report to the hotels would be rounded up and taken straight to the sites. It repeated its advice to Britons to stay home, and not to resist if confronted by Iraqi troops. Iraq said Friday it was detaining citizens of ``aggressive countries'' and placing them in areas that would be likely targets in the event of a U.S. attack such as Iraqi oil installations. On Saturday, Iraq said foreigners, along with Iraqis, would suffer any shortages provoked by U.N.-imposed economic sanctions.

DOC.HEAD: Oregon's Efforts to Reform Medicaid A Year Behind Schedule
DOC.TEXT:
A plan to ration services provided by Oregon's Medicaid program to ensure that basic health care is available to the largest number of people has fallen more than a year behind schedule. Approved by the Legislature in 1989, the program is the nation's first to consider eliminating expensive or ineffective treatments for Medicaid patients instead of providing total care, as most states do. A key to the program is an effort to establish a priority ranking of medical procedures that will be used to draw the line on Medicaid spending. But that effort encountered criticism when an initial ranking put crooked teeth near the top of its list and AIDS treatment near the bottom. Moreover, critics say any reduction in Medicaid coverage sets a dangerous precedent. But state Medicaid director Jean Thorne says health care costs are increasing at an alarming rate and she would far prefer to ration services than reduce the number of people who qualify for Medicaid. ``We constantly hear we've got to do something. ... Well, there's no way we can attack this problem without being controversial,'' she said. ``If the critics don't have anything better to offer, why not let us try this?'' Major health coverage celebrated its silver anniversary just last month. On July 30, 1965, President Lyndon Johnson signed into law Medicare and Medicaid, its companion health plan for the poor. Medical spending increased from $38 billion in 1965 to $70 billion in 1970. By 1980, health care costs had reached $236 billion. In 1983, the program was retooled. Payments to doctors and hospitals decreased, and what constitutes the poor was redefined. In Oregon, that meant a 6-year-old whose parents earn $575 a month was entitled to a heart transplant. But if the family's income totaled $576 a month, that child could not get so much as a booster shot. Even so, the state's Medicaid budget increased from $250 million during the 1985-87 biennium to $520 million during the current two-year budget period, according to Thorne. ``That's a 106 percent increase in funding, but the number of people covered has increased by only 33 percent,'' Thorne said. ``If we're going to increase spending, let's spread the money around more equitably.'' The Medicaid rationing program, approved by the 1989 Legislature, originally was to have begun on July 1. But state officials now concede there is little chance it will be ready by July 1, 1991. An 11-member panel of doctors, health care administrators and consumers has been poring over the priority list since September. They spent months devising a mathematical formula that would weigh the cost of a medical procedure against the severity of an illness and the benefit of treatment. Detection and prevention of AIDS was high on the list, but treatment for AIDS when a patient is close to death is near the bottom. So are liver and bone marrow transplants, which can run into the hundreds of thousands of dollars.
Thumb sucking was 37th, ahead of croup and congenital syphilis. That's because common ailments like thumb sucking are easily treated at a relatively low cost. ``The first draft was a data dump,'' said Paige Sipes-Metzler, executive director of the Oregon Health Services Commission. ``There will be another draft, possibly more than one. But, for the time being, we have something to work with.'' In June, the panel split into two subcommittees, each taking a different approach to the priority list. The panel has postponed until September any further decision on a ranking method. Meanwhile, no deadline has been set for the next draft of the priority list. ``We felt it was more important to get an extension of the deadline than to produce a list that doesn't work,'' said Sipes-Metzler, adding: ``It's never going to be a perfect list or satisfy everybody, but at least people will understand it.''

DOC.HEAD: United Arab Emirates Agrees To Deployment of Foreign Troops
DOC.TEXT: The United Arab Emirates announced Sunday it has agreed to the deployment of Arab and ``friendly'' forces on its territory to help defend the Persian Gulf region. Diplomatic sources said the statement gave the greenlight to deploy U.S., Egyptian and Pakistani troops here, but it was not immediately known if those nations plan to send any forces. The announcement by the United Arab Emirates' Foreign Ministry came on the eve of a scheduled visit by U.S. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney. On Sunday, Cheney was in Bahrain and Saudi Arabia, where he inspected U.S. troops at a desert air base. The Foreign Ministry said this oil-rich state supports the multinational force deployed in neighboring Saudi Arabia. The United States and Arab countries have sent troops to Saudi Arabia to defend the kingdom from possible attack by Iraq, which invaded neighboring Kuwait on Aug. 2. ``The United Arab Emirates has agreed to receive some Arab and friendly forces as a contribution to the Arab and international efforts being exerted to defend the region,'' said the Foreign Ministry statement released by the United Arab Emirates' official news agency. It did not specifically name any countries or say how many forces would be involved. Diplomatic sources said the statement gave approval to deploy U.S., Egyptian and Pakistani troops in the United Arab Emirates. ``We are not expecting more than 5,000 soldiers from each of the three states to be deployed in the U.A.E,'' said a Western diplomat, who could not be identified under his embassy's rules. The brief Foreign Ministry statement said the deployment of foreign troops in the country was in line with various international agreements, including the charters of the United Nations and the Arab League. The statement also said the deployment was in keeping with U.N. Security Council resolutions denouncing the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait and the decision taken at the Arab League summit in Cairo, Egypt, to send a multinational Arab force to defend threatened Persian Gulf states. The United States has undertaken a massive buildup of air, naval and ground troops in the gulf region after Iraqi troops were reported massing on Kuwait's border with Saudi Arabia. So far, foreign troops have been deployed only in Saudi Arabia, where U.S. forces have been joined by troops from Egypt, Morocco and Syria. Pakistan and Bangladesh have also agreed to send forces to Saudi Arabia. The six-nation Gulf Cooperation Council, which includes the United Arab Emirates, has also sent some troops to Saudi Arabia. Bahrain, which provides naval facilities to the United States, has reached agreement with Britain to open its air space and air bases to Royal Air Force squadrons of Jaguar and Tornado warplanes. The United Arab Emirates is located at the southern rim of the Persian Gulf, near the strategic Strait of Hormuz. The gulf is Iraq's outlet to the sea.

DOC.HEAD: Seven Die Moments After Takeoff
DOC.TEXT: The wreckage of a single-engine plane that apparently crashed just after takeoff was found Sunday with the bodies of seven victims, including four children. The plane left the Watertown airport Saturday night, and there was no hint of a problem until the pilot's wife reported Sunday morning that it was missing, Jefferson County sheriff Keith Mueller said. Authorities said searchers found the aircraft in a field about a half mile south of the airport. Mueller said authorities assumed the plane crashed on takeoff, not while coming back for a landing. There was no immediate indication of the cause. There were occasional thundershowers during the night, and the cornfield was shrouded in a thin haze during the morning search.

DOC.HEAD: `Fatal Vision' Again: New Evidence Promised in Jeffrey MacDonald Case
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS 1 graf with background on von Bulow case; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: the defense attorneys who won an acquittal for Claus von Bulow say they have new evidense`in the Jeffrey MacDonald case, the subject of the best-selling book ``Fatal Vision.'' Boston attorneys Harvey Silverglate and Alan Dershowitz plan to file a writ of habeas corpus to overturn the conviction of MacDonald, a Green Beret found guilty of murdering his wife and two daughters 22 years ago. The motion is due to be filed in U.S. District Court in Raleigh, N.C., sometime late next month or early October. Silverglate said last week that his team has uncovered forensic evidence in the highly publicized case that he says was hidden by the government during MacDonald's trial and subsequent appeal. He did not describe the evidence but said it corroborates a claim by a woman, now dead, who allegedly had told others she participated in the killings. ``Had it been available to Jeffrey MacDonald prior to the trial he would have been acquitted,'' said Silverglate. ``It will demonstrate that the story he told on the night of the murders was true.'' MacDonald, a Princeton-educated Army doctor, was convicted in 1979 of the bludgeoning and stabbing deaths of his pregnant wife, Colette, and two small daughters, Kimberly and Kristen, at their Fort Bragg, N.C., apartment in February 1970. MacDonald has maintained from the beginning that he and his family were attacked in their home by three men accompanied by a woman with ... hat, blond hair and boots. He said the woman chanted, ``Acid is groovy, kill the pigs.'' James Blackburn, who prosecuted the 1979 case, said Sunday he has been hearing the writ would be filed for more than a year. ``They have made that claim for a long time that they were going to file those motions,'' he said in a telephone interview from his home in Raleigh, where he is now an attorney. ``Once they are filed, I or the appropriate authorities will file a response. ``During the trial certainly absolutely no evidence was hidden from the defense that they were entitled to,'' he added. MacDonald, 46, is currently serving three consecutive life sentences at the Terminal Island federal penitentiary in San Pedro, Calif. He was transferred there from a Phoenix prison three years ago to be near his mother, Dorothy MacDonald, who is in poor health. ``I shouldn't be in prison,'' said MacDonald in a telephone interview from prison Friday. ``I'm going to keep fighting. ... I would never give up and just remain quietly in prison. I need to be vindicated.'' MacDonald asked Silverglate to take his case in 1983 and called him again last year with the new evidence. MacDonald, working from prison with a network of outside investigators and supporters, uncovered the new evidence, said attorney Phil Cormier, part of the defense team. MacDonald's case has followed a surreal, zigzag course through the years. Though he was originally a suspect in the case, the Army cleared him of charges after the longest pre-trial hearing in military history. He moved to Huntington Beach, Calif., and took a job as an emergency physician at a Long Beach hospital. His father-in-law, Freddy Kassab, initially his staunchest supporter, turned bitterly against him and conducted a virtual crusade against him. Kassab's persistence led in part to MacDonald's eventual indictment in 1975. MacDonald was tried and convicted of the crimes in 1979. A one-time suspect in the case, Helena Stoeckley, a chronic drug abuser, allegedly confessed to the crimes to various people on several occasions. The testimony of those people to whom Stoeckley allegedly confessed was not allowed during the trial. Stoeckley died in 1983. Silverglate said the new evidence links both Stoeckley and others to the crime scene and corroborates the testimony she gave witnesses for the first time. Author Joe McGinniss wrote the best-selling 1983 book ``Fatal Vision,'' in which he concluded MacDonald was guilty of the murders. The book was made into a highly rated television movie. MacDonald later sued McGinniss, claiming the author lied to gain his confidence and write the book. MacDonald won a $325,000 out-of-court settlement but was allowed to keep just $50,000. MacDonald said he is convinced he will finally be vindicated once the new evidence is made public. ``Then I can home and rebuild my life,'' he said. Blackburn characterized the legal maneuvering as ``another in a long series of attempts by MacDonald to deny that he was in fact involved, when a trial jury found he was guilty.'' Dershowitz and Silvergate made the celebrated defense of Claus von Bulow, who in 1985 was acquitted in Rhode Island of trying to murder his heiress wife, Martha ``Sunny'' von Bulow. Von Bulow had been convicted three years earlier.

DOC.HEAD: Tribal Fighting Claims 49 More Lives
LaserPhoto JOH2
DOC.TEXT: Police said Sunday that 49 blacks were killed in weekend tribal fighting waged with clubs, machetes and spears, bringing the death toll in a week of violence to 291. Soldiers were sent in to assist police in Tokoza and other townships east of Johannesburg, where battles broke out a week ago between Xhosas and Zulus, the country's two largest black tribes. Despite the increased security presence, 49 blacks were killed in Tokoza and five neighboring townships from Saturday morning through Sunday night, said police spokeswoman Lt. Ida van Zweel. Some victims were ritually castrated and had their hands cut off. Corpses were burned so badly police could not determine if the deceased were men or women. At least 213 blacks have died in Tokoza and neighboring townships since Aug. 12. Another 78 blacks have been killed in Soweto township southwest of Johannesburg during the same period. Xhosas on Sunday looted a deserted migrant workers hostel in Tokoza that had been occupied by thousands of Zulus a week earlier. Smoke rose from one hostel building that had been set alight. Police fired tear gas and shotguns to drive off looters. But when the police left, the looters returned, piling refrigerators, stoves and other items into cars and pickup trucks. There were scattered clashes and at least one Zulu was killed Sunday morning, witnesses said. Some Zulus returned to the hostel to pick up their possessions. ``They are trying to kill me,'' one Zulu man said of the Xhosas. ``It is a war.'' More than 6,000 armed Zulus remained at hostels in other parts of Tokoza, police said. ``Has the descent into a Beirut-style apocalypse begun?'' asked the Sunday Times, the country's largest-circulation newspapaper. ``In countless white homes, families watched the carnage and wondered if it would ever be possible to share power with people who regard the panga (machete) and the knobkerrie (club) as tools of political expression,'' the newspaper said in a front-page editorial. The fighting appears to be mostly a tribal conflict with a long history, but it also has political overtones. Nelson Mandela and many other leaders of the African National Congress, the largest opposition movement, are Xhosas. The rival Inkatha movement is a Zulu-based organization headed by Mangosuthu Buthelezi. According to local media reports Sunday, an ANC leader, Walter Sisulu, blamed Inkatha for the violence. But Buthelezi denied the allegation. ``It only stokes the violence when he (Sisulu) indulges in war talk,'' Buthelezi said. ``It's nonsense to say that Inkatha ... has imported the violence.'' Mandela and Buthelezi are old friends, and both have repeatedly called for an end to black faction fighting that has plagued the eastern province of Natal for five years and now is spreading to the Johannesburg area. But the two men have not met since Mandela was released from prison in February after serving 27 years for plotting to overthrow the white-led government. City Press, the country's largest black-oriented weekly, printed an open letter to Mandela and Buthelezi, urging them to hold immediate peace talks. ``Like millions of other black people, I cannot understand why you (Mandela) refuse to talk to Dr. Buthelezi, when at the drop of a hat you meet and talk to (President) F.W. de Klerk,'' wrote the paper's editor, Khulu Sibiya. ``I also fail to understand why in this century you (Buthelezi) still encourage tribalism among your people,'' Sibiya added. Both the ANC and Inkatha oppose apartheid, the system of racial segregation that allows the 5 million whites to maintain political and economic control over the 30 million blacks. However, the two black-led groups differ over tactics. The ANC has favored confrontational tactics such as boycotts and strikes, but recently agreed to suspend its ineffective armed struggle against the government. The relatively conservative Inkatha movement has never endorsed those methods, and favors capitalism as opposed to the socialist-oriented ANC.

DOC.HEAD: Sailors At Sea: Life-and-Death Video Games, Cigarette Smoke, Shotguns
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Subs grafs 17-19, ``Posted where xxx to CORRECT spelling of Aqaba
DOC.TEXT: The sailors aboard this guided missile destroyer control what their captain calls life-or-death ``video games'' in their mission to help tie the noose around Iraqi commerce. Young sailors closely studying an array of video screens puff on cigarettes. Swirls of smoke fill the air. Nearby, a specially trained boarding party stands ready with hand-held radios and shotguns. The USS Scott is on duty in the northern Red Sea. Hours after ships in the USS Eisenhower battle group confronted their first Iraqi vessels Saturday with shots across the bows of two tankers, Cmdr.
