Tom Corcoran is giving Defense Secretary Dick Cheney and a pool of Pentagon reporters a glimpse of the work aboard his ship. In the darkened, high-tech Combat Intelligence Center that is the warship's nerve center, sailors peer at giant circular screens, marked with neon symbols. They keep track of any air, sea or underwater threat to them or their lead ship. ``It's a little like being an air traffic controller in New York City or Chicago,'' Corcoran says. ``These guys are playing an enormous video game with life or death consequences.'' The threat of missiles, mines or enemy aircraft could bring death to those aboard the battle group as it spreads across this vital shipping lane on the Eastern Coast of Saudi Arabia. Corcoran shows Cheney the room's wide array of computers and weaponry guidance systems as he introduces young sailors who man some of the world's most potent weapons. Memories of past tragedies are in everyone's mind as Cheney views the Close-in Weapons System control panel, which directs a high-speed cannon. ``It's a last-ditch weapon, but it's so fast it can shoot the missiles right out of the sky,'' Lt.j.g. Daryl Hancock tells the defense secretary. ``They didn't use it on the Stark,'' he said, recalling the May 1987 incident in which an Iraqi Exocet missile inadvertently hit the USS Stark, killing 32 American sailors. At other screens that glow brilliant orange in the darkened room, sailors operate equipment to differentiate between friends and foes. Murmuring into headsets and drawing nervously on cigarettes, sailors follow aircraft along the commercial routes in the region, looking for any that stray from the known pathways. They look for any threat to the aircraft carrier USS Eisenhower, its crew of 5,200, or other U.S. ships and their crews. Corcoran's ship and the Eisenhower battle group have been at sea since March. Once the alert was sounded after Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait, the battle group went into an 18-hour frenzy to arm and supply itself for passage through the Suez Canal and into the Persian Gulf. Posted where it can stop ships entering or leaving the crucial Jordanian port of Aqaba, the Scott became one of the first ships to play an active role in President Bush's interception of Iraqi shipping. Aqaba has been the one loophole through which Iraq has transported goods since a United Nations-mandated trade embargo began. Most ships encountered by the Scott have been empty or posed no problem, Corcoran says, but a Cypriot freighter carrying aluminum chromate and other chemicals bound for Aqaba was told not to continue and turned back after an hour of radio communications, the captain says. Corcoran describes his crew as ``very, very alert, but very confident and relaxed about what they're doing.'' Aboard the Eisenhower, Cheney tells sailors and marines that they are involved in an international struggle for control of the world's oil reserves. Speaking of Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein, Cheney says, ``If he succeeds, he'll control the world economy.'' ``It`s tough, hard, dirty duty,'' Cheney says. ``But it is an enormously important deployment. This may be one of the most important moments for this nation for the rest of this century.''

DOC.HEAD: Honduras Armed Forces Chief Warns Of Crackdown on Left
DOC.TEXT: The armed forces chief Sunday warned of a renewed crackdown on leftists, saying guerrillas have infiltrated the military and planned a wave of attacks. ``Subversion is a reality in Honduras,'' said armed forces chief Arnulfo Cantarero Lopez in an interview with The Associated Press. ``And to counteract this, the country could return to the era of the doctrine of national security,'' Cantarero Lopez was referring to the period from 1982-1984 when the armed forces, then led by Gen. Gustavo Alvarez Martinez, followed a policy of detaining leftists in advance of attacks. Human rights organizations have accused the armed forces of killing about 300 people and causing the disappearance of 150 others during that period. Alvarez Martinez was shot to death in 1988 by the Cinchonero Popular Liberation Movement. Cantarero Lopez, 44, took over the post in January. In the interview, he said, ``The armed forces have been infiltrated by leftist guerrillas who are now trying to obtain resources to finance a wave of terrorism in Honduras.'' The general, interviewed in the city of Omoa 180 miles north of Tegucigalpa, suggested the leftists ``could be financed by international drug trafficking.'' ``This is logical because traditionally Honduras has been used as a trampoline for drug traffic between Colombia and the United States,'' he said. He did not specify what national security measures the 22,000-member army might take. But he said, ``The armed forces will do everything possible to block the communists from taking power in our nation ... and in this fight we hope to count on the aid of our people.'' ``The armed forces are vulnerable ... and have been infiltrated by subversion,'' said Cantarero Lopez. ``Military intelligence has detected numerous cases of guerrilla infiltration. ...'' He said a foiled bank robbery on Aug. 15 in El Zamorano, 18 miles east of Tegucigalpa, ``was the work of the Cinchoneros.'' No group has admitted attempting that robbery, which resulted in the deaths of six alleged guerrillas, three policemen, a bank guard and two other people. Six security agents were injured. ``The native guerrillas have been strengthened by the return of numerous Honduran leftists who for the past decade were in exile in Nicaragua,'' Cantarero Lopez said. ``The local insurgents have been trained for the past 10 years in the Soviet Union, Cuba and Libya. Because of that, they are well consolidated.'' ``We don't want to frighten the people, but the genesis of leftist violence has already been introduced in Honduras,'' he said. The Cinchoneros rose in Honduras in 1979 as an armed wing of the Communist Party, which has operated clandestinely since 1920.

DOC.HEAD: NASA Unloads Magellan Memory Banks to Diagnose Venus Orbiter's Woes
DOC.TEXT: Engineers continued to read data from Magellan's memory banks Sunday, looking for clues as to why the unmanned space probe temporarily lost contact with Earth during its mission around Venus. Franklin O'Donnell, a spokesman for the Jet Propulsion Laboratory in Pasadena, said the process of reading the craft's computer memory would take another four or five days. ``We're only getting data at 40 bits per second,'' O'Donnell said. ``Usually we read it at some thousand bits per second.'' In order to regain solid communication with Magellan, ground engineers commanded the craft to point a secondary antenna at Earth, O'Donnell said. Magellan's secondary antenna sends a much broader radio beam than the main antenna. But it sends data at a slower 40 bits per second, so unloading Magellan's memory banks proceeded at a crawl. But the contact with Magellan was ``quite solid,'' O'Donnell said. The engineers lost contact with Magellan Thursday night just after it bounced radar waves off Venus for a test and sent the information to Earth. They already know the malfunction made one of Magellan's computers stop sending signals called ``heartbeats'' to another computer, said David Okerson, a Magellan engineer assigned to JPL. That spurred Magellan to put itself into a series of protective safety modes that cut off contact with Earth, then sent radio signals across the heavens in a long effort to restore its radio link with controllers. A steady hookup was re-established Friday night after nearly 15 hours of no radio contact followed by eight hours of intermittent contact. ``The spacecraft administered CPR to itself,'' Okerson said. ``These protection mechanisms just saved our bacon.'' Jet Propulsion Laboratory spokeswoman Mary Beth Murrill said the time needed to diagnose and fix the problem likely would delay the planned Aug. 29 start of Magellan's mission to use radar to map Venus' cloud-covered surface. Normal contact with Magellan would be restored after it is ordered to leave the safety mode, point its main antenna at Earth and send data at a higher speed. Scientists hope to do that this week. Magellan was launched from the shuttle Atlantis on its $744 million Venus exploration mission on May 4, 1989. It went into orbit around Venus Aug. 10 after a circuitous trip of 948 million miles.

DOC.HEAD: 150,000 Gallons Of Gasoline Spills Into Delaware After Barge-Tanker Crash
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with no fish kills reported, tanker carrying cat feed stock, damaged tank emptied; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: A fuel barge and an oil tanker collided in the Delaware River early Sunday, spilling about 150,000 gallons of gasoline from the barge, the Coast Guard said. Environmental damage was expected to be minor. The tanker had hull damage in the bow area, but did not spill any of its cargo. No one was injured in the 12:45 a.m. accident 4 miles off Lewes at the mouth of Delaware Bay, Coast Guard officials said. The gasoline was not expected to hit the Delaware or New Jersey shorelines and did not pose an environmental threat, said Coast Guard Cmdr. Steve Gilbert in Philadelphia. No fish kills were reported by late Sunday. The Coast Guard said it did not plan to try a cleanup because the gas would evaporate. The Panamanian-registered tanker, the Faith I, was carrying cat feed stock, a substance used in refining overseas. It was loaded overseas and headed to Coast Eagle Point in New Jersey. The tugboat independence was pushing the barge Ocean 192 and was en route from Marcus Hook, Pa., to Boston, Gilbert said. Both were taken to Big Stone Anchorage where the barge was being unloaded. The anchorage is an area in the middle of Delaware Bay used as a parking lot for tankers which draw too much water to proceed farther up the river toward Wilmington and Philadelphia. The barge's seven tanks were loaded with 7.1 million gallons of gasoline and No. 2 fuel oil. The tank that spilled the fuel held 600,000 gallons of gasoline, Gilbert said. The remaining gas from the damaged tank was emptied onto another barge Sunday evening, Gilbert said. Further details of the accident were not released pending an investigation, Coast Guard officials said.

DOC.HEAD: Poll: People Like to Drive, But That Doesn't Mean They're Good at It
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 2, 6 and 8 to add percentage of respondents in `didn't know' category to make percents add up to 100.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Driving Poll-List
DOC.TEXT: Most Americans like to drive, but they don't know as much about it as they might think. An oil company's second annual poll of American motorists found that 81 percent of American drivers love or like to drive, while only 16 percent said they dislike driving and 3 percent didn't know. But when asked 10 questions about causes of accidents, how to avoid them and how to survive them, not one of the 500 licensed drivers participating in the poll answered all of them correctly. Among other findings in the poll, being issued Monday by Valvoline, automotive products subsidiary of Ashland Oil Inc. of Ashland: _Thirty percent of those surveyed rated New York City drivers the worst. Los Angeles was second, with 10 percent. _Fifty-four percent said they were better than other drivers, while 43 percent said their driving habits were about the same as others in their cities and towns. Two percent said they were worse drivers and 1 percent didn't know. _Nineteen percent said they always observed speed limits, while 58 percent said they did so most of the time. Seventeen percent said they sometimes obeyed speed signs, but 5 percent said they hardly ever did and 1 percent said they always ignored posted speed limits. _Thirty-two percent said gender was not a factor in driving skills, 36 percent said men were better drivers, 28 percent responded that women were better and 4 percent didn't know. Fifty-five percent of those surveyed were women and 45 percent were men. The nationwide poll was conducted through random telephone calls during June by Fleishman-Hillard Research Inc. of St. Louis. Its reported margin of error was 4 to 6 percentage points. The 10 true-or-false questions on driving safety and accident avoidance included ones on where and when most traffic deaths occur (rural, and at night); whether accidents are primarily due to mechanical failures (no); and whether seat belts give you a better chance in getting out of burning or submerged vehicle (yes _ just 28 percent got this right). Drivers also had the chance in the poll to sound off about what irks them the most about other drivers. At the top of the list was failure to use turn signals, cited by 24 percent of the participants. Other bad habits cited included cutting off or pulling in front of other drivers, driving too slowly and tailgating. On driving issues, 90 percent said motorcyclists should be required by law to wear helmets and 79 percent said air bags should be standard equipment in passenger cars and trucks. Only 30 percent said they don't want permissible blood-alcohol levels lowered to make drunk-driving laws more strict. Sixty-eight percent said they want tougher laws. And 57 percent agreed that alternative fuels, such as methanol and natural gas, are practical alternatives to gasoline.

DOC.HEAD: Air Guard's Deployment Changes Nature of a Town
DOC.TEXT: It's a lot easier to get a window booth these days at Joann's Pantry, a lunch time favorite of the West Virginia Air National Guard's 167th Tactical Airlift Group. ``A lot of our regulars are over in the Middle East,'' said Bob Garza, who manages the restaurant. ``I would say our lunch business has been down 50 percent since they pulled out last week.'' The 1,200-member group drops men and equipment from C-130 turboprop aircraft into battle zones. It has shipped at least 194 volunteers to various locations, including the Middle East, since Aug. 8. Thirty unit members were sent to Saudi Arabia, said Adj. Gen. Joseph Skaff, state secretary for public safety. Skaff, who commands the air guard and the state's Army National Guard, said most of the rest were filling in at U.S. bases for regular troops deployed to the Middle East. The group, based in this northeastern West Virginia town, is comprised mainly of West Virginians but includes members from nearby Maryland, Pennsylvania and Virginia. ``No one around here is saying anything,'' said Garza, 42, as he served food on a slower-than-usual Friday. ``I haven't really heard much about it and we're familiar and close to a lot of them.'' Air guard members quickly volunteered for duty after Iraq invaded Kuwait and the United States began moving troops to the region. Their response carried on a patriotic tradition, said Jack Koch, a retired Air National Guard colonel and former air commander of the 167th. West Virginia has, on a per capita basis, more Medal of Honor winners than any other state, Koch said. It also has the greatest number of war volunteers and the highest number of war casualties, on a per capita basis. There are few outward signs of the mobilization around this prosperous town of 14,000, where many residents commute to work in Washington. Residents are as likely to shrug as to answer when asked about the call-up. ``Before it was communism, now it's oil,'' said Jim Mahares, 40, as he tended his hot dog stand on the town's main street. ``No one has said a single thing to me about this,'' said F. Page Burdette, editor of The Morning Journal. ``We have received no letters to the editor, no phone calls, nothing. ``Now, if you ask them `What do you think about gas prices going up?' that's different,'' Burdette said. ``They're thinking about their pocketbooks.'' National Guard members from at least 21 states are part of the U.S. mobilization. The Pentagon has refused to say how many guardsmen were deployed. But information from state capitals indicates that more than 1,000 air crew members, technicians, communications experts and medical personnel have volunteered for duty. Skaff said West Virginia guardsmen and their aircraft could be close to the fighting if a shooting war breaks out. ``These aircraft would be in country, moving troops from a port to an operational base,'' Skaff said. ``We're the local commuters if you will.''

DOC.HEAD: Congressmen Advocate Firing on Iraqi Vessels
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Subs 14th graf, ``CBS News xxx to delete reference to the 35 Americans being same ones who previously in hotel
DOC.TEXT: Two influential Democratic congressmen said Sunday that U.S. warships should fire on Iraqi vessels that ignore orders to stop, even if that meant an act of war against Iraq. Rep. Les Aspin, D-Wis., chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, said U.S. warships should be prepared to fire on ships that try to break the embargo against Iraq. ``I think that's what a blockade is all about,'' Aspin said on NBC-TV's ``Meet the Press'' program. ``You give people ample warning to stop and to be searched and to be checked out, and then if they don't, then of course you proceed to try and disable the ship.'' U.S. Navy vessels in the Persian Gulf region fired warning shots at two Iraqi oil tankers Saturday, following President Bush's orders Thursday to interdict shipments in and out of Iraq using ``the minimum force necessary.'' The oil tankers proceeded without stopping and were being monitored by U.S. warships. The Pentagon said it knew nothing about a claim by the official Iraqi news agency's of a third firing Sunday. Rep. Lee Hamilton, D-Ind., chairman of the House Middle East subcommittee, said any firing on an Iraqi vessel ``would be an act of war'' under international law. Hamilton said that if Bush orders ships to open fire, ``I believe that the Congress will support the president.'' The White House dismissed an offer by Iraqi President Saddam Hussein to release Westerners held since the Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait if Bush offers written guarantees that U.S. forces will be withdrawn from Saudi Arabia and the economic boycott against Iraq is ended. ``It seems we're getting a daily seminar of Iraqi ridicule these days,'' said White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater. He said the latest Iraqi proposal ``doesn't have much relationship to our objective and contains no new relevant proposals and makes no reference to the United Nations and Arab League calls for them to leave Kuwait.'' Washington has insisted that U.S. military action in the Middle East will end only after Saddam removes his troops from Kuwait and the ousted Kuwaiti government is restored to power. Fitzwater commented on Air Force One as Bush was returning to Washington from his Maine vacation home Sunday afternoon for a meeting with national security adviser Brent Scowcroft. In related news Sunday: _Undersecretary of State for Political Affairs Robert Kimmitt said on the NBC program that there was no confirmation yet the Iraqis were carrying through on threats to move Americans and other foreigners to vital targets to deter a U.S. attack. He said the State Department was urging the estimated 3,000 Americans trapped in Iraq and occupied Kuwait to stay in their homes but not to resist if Iraqi authorities try to move them. _CBS News, quoting a U.S. consular official in Baghdad, reported that 35 Americans have been taken to U.S. diplomatic quarters in the Iraqi capital. A State Department official, asked about the report, said ``We can't comment on that at this time.'' _Iraqi Ambassador to the United States Mohammed Sadiq al-Mashat, interviewed on ABC-TV's ``This Week With David Brinkley'' program, rejected suggestions that Iraq was violating international norms by refusing to allow Americans and other Westerners to leave Iraq and Kuwait. ``When you deny our children food and milk, what do you expect?'' he said, adding that the United States should work for peace rather than ``beating the drums of war'' because ``we are on the brink of a catastrophe for everybody.'' _Sen. Ted Stevens, R-Alaska, said Defense Secretary Dick Cheney has asked Transportation Secretary Samuel Skinner to authorize the use of armed Coast Guard personnel for boarding ships in the Persian Gulf region. But a Coast Guard spokesman, Lt. Cmdr. Kim Krzywicki, said the agency had heard nothing about such an assignment. The White House has shied away from referring to U.S. Navy action in the Middle East as a blockade, but Hamilton, also speaking on NBC, said ``I think the lawyers may quibble about these words, but I don't think the public does.'' Hamilton and Aspin cautioned, however, that Bush will not have support for use of military force against Iraq unless Iraqi President Saddam Hussein escalates the current war of nerves. ``The key is that the president and the Congress must not move too far out in front of the consensus,'' both domestic and international, Hamilton said.

DOC.HEAD: Stealth Fighters En Route to Middle East
DOC.TEXT: The Air Force showed off its once-secret Stealth fighter Sunday as 22 of the attack planes headed toward the Mideast in a show of force intended to warn Iraq of U.S. air superiority. Reporters were invited to Langley Air Force Base to view the F-117A planes as they landed here en route to joining the military buildup in the Persian Gulf. The United States has said the buildup is defensive and intended to assure that the Iraqis, who invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2, don't attempt further military adventures. Col. Anthony Tolin, until recently a wing commander of the Stealth fighters, which are based at Nellis Air Fore Base in Nevada, acknowledged the F-117A is not a defensive weapon. ``I guess it would be tough to classify the F-117A as a purely defensive weapon. It's defensive nature is its ability to penetrate enemy radar without detection,'' Tolin said. He said the presence of the planes in the gulf could be an important psychological weapon. ``They give us an ability, should we need it, to get in with the least amount of casualties and attack those important targets if necessary,'' Tolin said. The planes are scheduled to leave for the gulf Monday afternoon. The Air Force has already sent F-15 fighter planes and A-10s since Iraq moved on Kuwait and massed troops on Kuwait's border with Saudi Arabia. The A-10 is a ground support aircraft designed to take out tanks and other armored vehicles. Tolin said the Stealth fighter was designed ``to penetrate enemy defenses, to locate high priority targets and to deliver ordinance.'' The plane was once considered so secret the Air Force flew it only at night on test missions high above the Nevada desert. The plane was designed and built by Lockheed Co.'s super-secret ``Skunk Works'' in Burbank, Ca. The Air Force says it has 56 of the planes. The F117A and the newer B2 Stealth bomber got their ``stealth'' nickname because they are designed to be nearly invisible to radar. The F117A has seen combat only once, when they bombed a target using laser-guided bombs during the December 1989 Panama invasion. Tolin left his job as commander of the 37th Tactical Fighter Wing at Nellis two days ago. He is now assistant deputy chief of staff of the Tactical Air Command at Langley. The planes began landing shortly after 3:30 p.m. About the size of an F-15, the ungainly matte black jets gently settled onto the runway and slowed with the help of a drogue chute. At $42.6 million per plane, not including the research and development costs, the fighters are one of the world's most expensive planes. Tolin said the planes are remarkably easy to fly, but was closemouthed about the plane's capabilities and armament. He was more talkative about the plane's odd appearance. ``I'm often asked how I can love something this ugly,'' he said as another F-117A landed. ``Tom Clancy, the author, gave me a good story that can explain it. ``The Scottish wolfhound is considered the ugliest dog in all of Scotland. But the owners of Scottish wolfhounds are always quick to point out that there are no wolves in Scotland.'' Clancy is the author of ``The Hunt for Red October'' and other thrillers with military themes.

DOC.HEAD: Two Planes Crash Into Long Beach Harbor
DOC.TEXT: Two small planes collided over Long Beach Harbor and crashed into the water Sunday afternoon, authorities said. Scuba divers were searching for the pilots and any others on board. After the collision, one plane crashed just outside the breakwater and the other plunged into the water near the entrance to the Southern California harbor, said lifeguard Tim Murphy. It was not immediately known what type of aircraft were involved or how many people were on board. Authorities described the planes as small, private aircraft. No injuries or damage were reported to people or boats in the harbor, authorities said. Scuba divers were searching for passengers and debris from the planes. ``The area has been marked by buoys where some floating debris and an oil slick is, but it's pretty deep and it going to be a pretty difficult task,'' Murphy said. The Federal Aviation Administration said the planes were not in contact with air traffic controllers when they collided. The National Transportation Safety Board was investigating.

DOC.HEAD: Kennedy Brother-in-Law Stephen E. Smith Dies
DOC.TEXT: Stephen E. Smith, who managed brother-in-law John F. Kennedy's presidential campaign, died Sunday in his Manhattan home after a long illness. He was 62. Smith, who was married to the former Jean Kennedy, also ran several family businesses and advised the family on financial matters and political campaigns, said Eddie Martin, a spokesman for Sen. Edward Kennedy, D-Mass. ``For 34 years, from the day he married Jean, Steve was like a brother in our family. He was the wisest adviser, the most skillful campaign manager, and the best friend that any of us ever had,'' the senator said through his spokesman. ``There wouldn't have been a Camelot without Steve Smith.'' The spokesman who released news of the death did not give a cause. Smith's survivors include his wife and his four children, William, Stephen Jr., Amanda and Kym, all of whom were with him when he died, Martin said. A funeral Mass is scheduled for 10 a.m. Tuesday at St. Thomas More's Church. Viewing will be from 5 p.m. to 7:30 p.m. at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel.

DOC.HEAD: Sri Lankan Rebels, Government Clash; At Least 22 Dead
DOC.TEXT: Tamil rebels killed nine soldiers in an ambush on the west coast, and government forces killed at least 13 Tamil guerrillas in the east, military officials said Sunday. The soldiers were ambushed while patrolling near Karadipuval, about 85 miles north of Colombo, on Saturday, according to the officials, who cannot be identified under briefing rules. They gave no other details on that clash. In the east, a helicopter gunship Saturday strafed about 30 Tamil Tiger guerrillas who were closing in on Colony 11, a Moslem village in the Ampara district, the officials said. They said 10 to 12 of the guerrillas were killed. The government says the Tigers have massacred nearly 400 Moslems this month, but the Tigers claim the killings were the work of pro-government Tamils who are trying to discredit the Tigers. Three other Tigers were killed Saturday by police commandos during search operations near Akkaraipattu, and a Moslem civilian was killed in a cross-fire between the police and Tigers near Colony 13, the officials said. Both those villages are in the Ampara district, about 120 miles east of Colombo. The Tigers have been fighting the Sinhalese-controlled government since 1983 in the quest for a separate homeland for their ethnic minority. In the past two years, they also have accused Moslems of supporting the government and attacked them too. At least 14,000 people have died in the insurrection. Tamils comprise 18 percent of Sri Lanka's 16 million people and say the Sinhalese discriminate against them in jobs and education. Sinhalese make up 75 percent of the population of this island nation off the southern tip of India. Moslems account for 7 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Indians Agree to End Rail Blockade in Ontario
DOC.TEXT: Indian leaders on Sunday agreed to end a blockade of CN Rail trains in northern Ontario, but other rail lines remained blocked by Indian bands pressing land claims, police said. After meeting with police, Indians from the Long Lake band dismantled their blockade about 180 miles northeast of Thunder Bay on Lake Superior. The four-day protest had blocked east-west trains on Canadian National Rail lines, the nation's main transcontinental rail link, for almost a week. But Indians from the Pic Mobert band continued to block Canadian Pacific rail tracks near White River, Ontario. The Indian bands have been blocking the rail lines to call attention to their land claims and demands for meetings with federal Indian Affairs Minister Tom Siddon. They are also expressing support for Mohawk Indians in Quebec who have been engaged in an armed standoff with army troops and authorities in another land dispute. Meanwhile, in British Columbia, the Seton-Portage Indian band continued to block the BC Rail link between Vancouver and Prince George, defying a court injunction to clear the tracks. Those Indians set up the blockade Friday because they were upset with the response by British Columbia officials to their land claim proposals. Details of the agreement to end the blockade of the CN Rail line were not immediately available. ``We'll be moving quickly to restore normal traffic,'' CN Rail spokesman Roger Cameron said late Sunday from Montreal. He said the railway would rescind layoff notices sent to about 300 employees because of slowdowns caused by the blockade. Sunday's meeting between police and the Indians was held in a grassy field near the blocked CN Rail line. On Saturday, the railway obtained a court injunction Saturday ordering the Long Lake Indians to clear tracks running through their reservation, said a statement by the provincial police. CN service between Winnipeg and Toronto had been severely disrupted since the blockade started Monday. Several trains a day were canceled and hundreds of carloads of freight were delayed, Cameron said. Talks between Pic Mobert leaders and mediator George Broeffle on Saturday failed to settle the dispute after the Indians rejected the latest government offer. British Columbia Rail obtained an injunction from the British Columbia Supreme Court on Saturday night ordering the Seton-Portage band to stop halting traffic of the line south of Lillooet, about 110 miles northeast of Vancouver. But the 70 Indians blocking the tracks refused to move Sunday when railway officials arrived with three Royal Canadian Mounted Police officers, said BC Rail spokesman Barrie Wall.

DOC.HEAD: Saddam Offers to Free Foreigners if U.S. Pulls Out, Ends Embargo
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS two grafs after 22nd `U.N. Secretary-General...' to ADD U.N. meeting to discuss military action; pickup graf 23 pvs `The United...'

DOC.TEXT: Saddam Hussein offered on Sunday to free all foreigners in Iraq and Kuwait if the United States promises to withdraw its forces from Saudi Arabia and guarantees that an international economic embargo will be lifted. U.S. and British officials dismissed the initiative. As a goodwill gesture, Iraq said it will immediately free all detainees from Austria, Switzerland, Sweden, Finland and Portugal. Those countries account for fewer than 600 of the 21,000 Westerners who have been trapped in Kuwait and Iraq for the last three weeks. ``When the above-mentioned items are met, we will use our constitutional powers to allow all the foreigners to travel out of Iraq, each according to his wish,'' the official Iraqi News Agency quoted the Iraqi president as saying. In the meantime, Saddam said, the remaining foreign captives, including 3,000 Americans, will be held at vital Iraqi targets to avoid the ``flood of fire'' that will result if U.S.-led forces attack Iraq. CBS News reported from Baghdad on Sunday that 35 Americans, including four women and three children, have taken refuge at U.S. diplomatic ``quarters'' in the Iraqi capital. It did not specify what it meant by quarters. The report quoted the officer in charge of the U.S. Embassy in Baghdad, Joseph Wilson, as saying he and his staff were doing everything possible to prevent Americans from being rounded up by Iraqi authorities. Asked about the report, a spokesman at the State Department said: ``We can't make a comment on that at this time.'' One of the refuge-seeking Americans, Vivian Hill, of Orlando, Fla., told CBS that her biggest concern was ``that it could get worse. We could be taken from here. I wouldn't be surprised. We've contemplated that happening.'' CBS also reported that some other Americans had been taken from a Baghdad hotel and dispersed as human shields at strategic locations, including a sulphuric acid plant at Al Qaim, munitions and chemical sites in Baiji and Taji, and a chemical and artillery production facility at Al Iskandariyah. Saddam's statement, also carried on Iraqi television, was described as an open letter to the families of the detained foreigners. It was Saddam's second attempt to negotiate an end to the Persian Gulf crisis since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2 in a dispute over oil, money and territory. He later annexed the oil-rich nation. Earlier, Saddam had linked an Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait with an Israeli pullout from its occupied territories and a Syrian withdrawal from Lebanon. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater dismissed the latest Iraqi proposal. ``It seems we're getting a daily seminar of Iraqi ridicule these days,'' said Fitzwater, who was traveling on Air Force One en route from Kennebunkport, Maine to Washington. He said the Iraqi proposal ``doesn't have much relationship to our objective and contains no new relevant proposals and makes no reference to the United Nations and Arab League calls for them to leave Kuwait.'' When President Bush sent thousands of troops to defend Saudi Arabia against a possible Iraqi attack, he also demanded that Iraqi troops unconditionally withdraw from Kuwait and restore its monarchy to power. In London, a British Foreign Office spokesman also dismissed Saddam's latest initiative, saying, ``It doesn't represent any real progress at all.'' Saddam gave a lengthy justification Sunday for the invasion and reiterated Iraq's longstanding claims to Kuwait. Earlier Iraqi announcements have ordered Westerners living in Iraq and Kuwait to report to specific hotels, prompting fears they will be interned. Iraq also has said that foreign babies and elderly people will be the first to suffer if the embargo results in food and medicine shortages in Iraq. Thomas R. Pickering, the U.S. ambassador to the United Nations, said on Saturday that Saddam has made it clear he intends ``to hold hostage all foreigners.'' U.S. officials previously had avoided using the word hostage. U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar, meanwhile, dispatched two senior U.N. officials to Baghdad to urge Iraqi officials to free its detainees. Perez de Cuellar said Saddam had sent a letter requesting that the envoys be sent, but he did not elaborate. The United States and the other four permanent members of the U.N. Security Council met Sunday at the French Mission in New York and explored the possibility of joint military action under the U.N. charter, Western diplomats said. The meeting was inconclusive, but some members felt the council should move toward some kind of military action, said a diplomat who spoke on condition of anonymity. Informal private consultations of the council were likely Monday. The United States is pouring thousands of soldiers into Saudi Arabia, and U.S. officials have said the deployment could reach 200,000 men and women. Other Western and Arab countries have contributed troops to the growing multinational force, but it is still made up of mostly U.S. soldiers. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said on Sunday that Iraq has massed 200,000 troops and more than 1,000 tanks on the Saudi border. ``Should Saddam Hussein be foolish enough to launch an attack on Saudi Arabia, we would be able to do a very effective job of making him pay a bit of a price for that,'' said Cheney, who visited U.S. soldiers in Saudi Arabia and seamen on the USS Eisenhower in the Red Sea. ``Obviously, I'll be more comfortable once we've got more forces in the country.'' DOC.HEAD: Psychologist B.F. Skinner Dead at 86
DOC.NOTE: EDS: INSERTS 1 graf after 4th graf, `While remembered...' with reaction from friend, picks up 5th graf, `Burrhus Frederic...; INSERTS 2 grafs after 11th graf pvs, `But his...' with contrast to cognitive psyhology, reaction from psychologist; picks up 12th graf pvs, `Skinner, in...'; SUBS last graf with 2 grafs to include mention of honors; no pickup

DOC.TEXT: B.F. Skinner, one of the century's leading psychologists who believed human behavior could be engineered to build a better world, died of leukemia. He was 86. Skinner died Saturday at Mount Auburn Hospital in this university city, a hospital administrator said. He was the patriarch of the school of thought known as behaviorism and the inventor of the ``Skinner box,'' a tool he used to demonstrate his theory that rewarded behavior is repeated. While remembered by many _ and sometimes scorned _ for teaching pigeons to play pingpong and guide missiles, his novel ``Walden Two'' was required reading for a generation of college students in the 1960s and 1970s. ``He was certainly the leading psychologist of his time,'' said Richard Herrnstein, a psychology professor at Harvard who knew Skinner for 38 years. Burrhus Frederic Skinner _ B.F. to the world, Fred to his friends _ spent most of his career at Harvard, where he applied his observations of animals to the motives and manipulation of human conduct. Skinner's views were based on his principle of ``operant behavior,'' the idea that seemingly spontaneous action is regulated through rewards and punishment. People don't shape the world, he said, the world shapes them. In the months leading up to his death, Skinner remained active, preparing a defense of his research that explored the uses of positive and negative reinforcement to improve human behavior. ``I will be dead in a few months,'' he said in an interview last month. ``But it hasn't given me the slightest anxiety or worry or anything; I always knew I was going to die.'' Skinner believed that human behavior is predictable, just like a chemical reaction. Since people were run through their paces by their environment, ``behavioral technology'' could put them to work to create a happy and safe world, free of overpopulation, war and pollution. Many psychologists disagreed with his theories. Of his contemporaries, Skinner once said, ``I can mention only one or two who really very seriously changed their attitudes toward the study of behavior as a result of anything I have ever done or said.'' But his application of the ideas of the Russian physiologist Ivan Pavlov left an indelible stamp on American society. Parents use his ``operant conditioning'' each time they praise a behavior they want and punish one they don't want. Skinner's work was opposed to that of the cognitive psychologists, who emphasize the unconscious structures of the human mind that are unaffected by conditioning. Skinner saw no difference between brain and mind. ``What he did was decry psychological theory and place the emphasis on what behavior could be observed,'' said Albert Ullman, a retired professor of sociology at Tufts University in Medford. Skinner, in his later years a lean man with a fine-featured, patrician face beneath a broad expanse of forehead, was born March 20, 1904, in Susquehanna, Pa., the elder son of Grace Burrhus, an amateur musician, and William Skinner, a lawyer. After majoring in English at Hamilton College in Clinton, N.Y., Skinner decided he wanted to be a writer. He sent some short stories to the poet Robert Frost, who wrote back: ``You are worth twice anyone else I have seen in prose this year.'' Skinner went to Manhattan's Greenwich Village to work on his craft but after a year or so gave it up. ``I discovered the unhappy fact that I had nothing to say,'' he recalled, ``and went on to graduate study in psychology, hoping to remedy that shortcoming.'' He was attracted to the work of John B. Watson, the founder of behaviorism, and earned his doctorate from Harvard in 1931. He taught at the University of Minnesota and Indiana University before joining the Harvard faculty in 1947. It was at Harvard that the life-long tinkerer devised the Skinner box, a soundproof enclosure with buttons or levers that animals press to receive food in return for doing whatever the experimentor wants them to do. The box provides a precise way to observe, record and measure behavior. It is widely used by psychologists, many of whom are not Skinnerians, as well as by drug researchers, who watch the way animals react to new medicines. Skinner preferred to call his invention an ``operant conditioning apparatus.'' He employed it to teach rats, and later pigeons, to perform amazing tricks. Birds learned to play the piano, walk in figure eights and dance. Table tennis, though, might have carried things too far. Asked once what he would do differently if given the chance, he replied: ``Just one thing. I performed one experiment that has never ceased to reverberate. I've been laughed at by enemies and kidded by friends. If I could do it all over again, I'd never teach those pigeons to play pingpong.'' During World War II, he rigged up a way for a pigeon to guide a missile to its goal by pecking on an image of the target when it appeared on a screen. The government never adopted the method. In the 1940s, Skinner also invented something he thought could revolutionize child rearing _ his air crib, known less reverently as the baby box. The crib was a roomy, insulated, temperature-controlled box with a window. Inside, the baby could sleep and play comfortably without blankets or clothes. Skinner's younger daughter, Deborah, was raised in an air crib for 2{ years. But like the pigeon-run missiles, it never caught on. Many people's understanding of Skinner's vision for society came from his novel ``Walden Two,'' which was published in 1948. In it, he described a tightly controlled utopia in which people were motivated by positive and negative reinforcements _ rewards and punishment. During the 1960s and beyond, the book attracted a kind of cult following. Hundreds of thousands of copies were sold, many to young people intrigued by Skinner's image of a better world. In the society he drew, everyone is happy. People don't know the meaning of envy and jealousy. Buildings are communally owned, and everyone helps out with chores. There's time for reading and painting, song and friendship. The key to this community's success is child rearing. Youngsters are raised together. Discipline is strict, and children are taught to rein in their desires though self-control exercises. Some critics decried his model society as tyrannical. Others thought that a world populated by such happy and well-behaved people would be bland indeed. Said psychologist Carl Rogers: ``I can only feel that he was choosing these goals for others, not himself. I would hate to see Skinner become well-behaved, as that term would be defined for him by behavioral scientists. And the most awful fate I can imagine for him would be to have him constantly happy. It is the fact that he is very unhappy about many things which makes me prize him.'' Skinner recorded his work in a series of scholarly books, including ``The Behavior of Organisms,'' ``Verbal Behavior'' and ``Science and Human Behavior.'' He wrote a three-volume autobiography, and as he turned 80 reflected on aging in ``Enjoy Old Age.'' After his retirement in 1974, Skinner maintained an office at Harvard, walking the 2{ miles each day from his Cambridge home. He also spoke occasionally at scientific societies, and in 1982 gave the American Psychological Association a report on how to cope with the frailties of age: Build a stimulating environment, create memory tricks, work less and rest the mind between intellectual workouts. His honors included the National Medal of Science, which he won in 1968, and the gold medal of the American Psychological Association, in 1971. Skinner is survived by his daughters, Deborah Buzan and Julie Vargas, and his wife, Yvonne.

DOC.HEAD: Precautionary Evacuations Begun After High Water Threatens Indiana Dam
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 4 grafs with dam leaking, more rain forecast; picks up 3rd graf pvs, `Other residents...
DOC.TEXT: A A leaky dam forced the evacuation of a hospital and apartments for the elderly Sunday after high water threatened to break a dam on Lake Manitou, police said. ``If we don't get any more rain, we'll be all right,'' said Mayor Philip Thompson, who was supervising the sandbagging efforts of volunteers, police and civil defense officials. Forecasters predicted thunderstorms could bring two more inches of rain early Monday, and the National Weather Service issued a flash flood watch. Leaks appeared in the dam on Saturday, after six inches of rain pushed the lake about two feet above flood stage. The lake rose at about one inch per hour until cresting at 1 p.m. Sunday, Fulton County Conservation Officer Dick Eurit said. At least 100 people were evacuated from the area immediately below the dam, officials said. Other residents of the lightly populated area below the dam were advised to leave their homes or prepare to evacuate if the dam were to break, said Fulton County chief jailer Robert Bryant. Twenty-eight patients at Woodlawn Hospital were dismissed, taken to other hospitals, nursing homes or the local high school gymnasium shortly after midnight, officials said. Volunteers, fire crews and civil defense officials laid about 13,000 sand bags along the dam early Sunday, Bryant said. ``It's holding at this point. Our main problem is now we're expecting another 2 to 3 inches of rainfall tonight,'' he said Sunday afternoon. The U.S. Army Corps of Engineers brought large pumps to attempt to lower the lake, the National Weather Service said. Lake Manitou is about 12 feet above Mill Creek, which flows along the eastern edge of Rochester, a town of 5,000 in north-central Indiana, and empties into the Tippecanoe River. A complete failure of the dam could raise Mill Creek by 6 feet, the weather service said. It would crest in Rochester within a half hour of a dam failure. ``The biggest problem it would affect would be our hospital. If the dam was to go out, a large quantity of water would hit it,'' he said. A similar threat faced the west-central Wisconsin town of Tomah on Saturday. About 1,500 people evacuated when high water threatened to rupture the Lake Tomah Dam on the Lemonweir River. About 700 people stayed out of their homes during the night but began returning Sunday. But flowing though the gates of the dam raised the level of the Lemonweir River and caused alarm downriver in Mauston and New Lisbon. The Juneau County sheriff's office said late Sunday the Lemonweir was within a foot of flood stage. Tomah got about 8 inches of rain in three hours late Friday. The dam was reinforced with about 20,000 sandbags and its reservoir dropped eight inches by Saturday night after the floodgates were opened, said Tomah Fire Chief Tom Flock.

DOC.HEAD: Thousands of Scientists Participate in Televised Plant Biotech Symposium
DOC.TEXT: PULLMAN, Wash. (A) _ A scientist in Egypt asked a question about wheat, which was answered by an expert in West Germany. Observers in Pullman and 80 other sites around the world listened in on the exchange. The question from Cairo was one of more than 100 raised Saturday during the first plant biotechnology symposium to be conducted via worldwide telecommunications. Eight satellites carried the discussions _ between international panels of scientists at the Max Planck Institute for Genetics Research in West Germany and at Washington State University _ to 80 viewing stations around the world. Viewers' questions, relayed by facsimile machines, were passed on to the panels, which had experts from Mexico, Australia, the United States, Germany, India and the Soviet Union. C.A. ``Bud'' Ryan, director of Washington State's Institute of Biological Chemistry, began planning the teleconference two years ago. Afterward, he said he was ``thrilled beyond my wildest expectations.'' ``We didn't try to do this as a symposium that is going to bring in new science. It was an experiment in the spirit of Ed Murrow,'' Ryan said. ``The news is happening so fast that you want to sit back with the people that are making it and analyze what it means.'' The question from Cairo _ about wheat's tolerance to drought and salinity _ was answered in Germany by Jozef St. Schell, who said it was too early to say when strains of wheat more capable of surviving salty water and dry spells would be developed. Most of the questions came from developing nations, said James Cook, a WSU biotechnolgy researcher who monitored the facsimile machines. Biotechnology, which include genetic modification of plants and animals so they can resist disease or be more productive, affects everything from the color of flowers to plants' defense against insects. Advances in communications technology, meanwhile, should allow more scientific teleconferences to help spread new information, said Donald E. Hanna, program coordinator and associate vice provost for extended university services at Washington State University. The broadcast ``really represents a first for this kind of program,'' Hanna said. The teleconference, which cost $115,000, was sponsored by Washington State, the Planck Institute, the U.S. Department of Agriculture, the West German government, and private communications companies. It was relayed to 60 U.S. universities and research centers, as well as to Germany, Egypt, Pakistan, India, Thailand, Morocco, Malawi, Mexico and Barbados, Hanna said.

Investors dumped stocks and dollars as oil and gasoline prices shot higher and uncertainty intensified about the desert standoff against Iraq and its effect on the weak U.S. economy. Friday, on Wall Street, sellers took the offensive for most of the day amid speculation that the economy _ already in a recession by some accounts _ would suffer further from expensive oil resulting from Iraq's seizure of Kuwait and its threat to other key Persian Gulf oil states.

Unleaded gasoline hit a record high on the New York Mercantile Exchange, as crude oil prices shot up and speculators kept betting that the Middle East standoff would curtail supplies. September wholesale unleaded gas futures soared Friday to as high as 96.25 cents before settling at 95.97 cents per gallon, up 8.5 cents from Thursday's record close. West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark U.S. crude, finished up $1.27 at $26.83 per barrel.

Record exports and shrinking oil imports helped push the nation's merchandise trade deficit to a seven-year low in June, the government reported. Analysts saw oil as a problem in coming months because of the Mideast crisis. The Commerce Department said Friday that the deficit dropped to $5.07 billion, a 34.7 percent decline from $7.77 billion in May and the lowest since a $3.96 billion imbalance was posted in June 1983.

_ JIDDAH, Saudi Arabia (AP) _ Saudi Arabia is ready to increase its oil output by up to 2 million barrels a day to help offset the world shortfall caused by the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait, the oil minister indicated. Oil Minister Hisham Nazer told a news conference in Jiddah Saturday that his country would have ``no alternative'' but to increase oil production unilaterally if OPEC does not convene an emergency meeting requested by Saudi Arabia.

_ ATLANTIC CITY, N.J. (AP) _ Developer Donald Trump's financial footing became more precarious when the state Casino Control Commission said it would not rule on his complex financial bailout until Tuesday. Acting Chairwoman Valerie Armstrong said Friday the commission needed more time to review more than 1,000 pages of documents. Trump attorneys had argued that any delay beyond Friday could jeopardize Trump's $65 million bailout and trigger a chain of bankruptcies in his debt-riddled Atlantic City casino and Manhattan real estate empire.

The Casino Control Commission unanimously approved a restructuring plan for Resorts International that leaves owner Merv Griffin with just 21.5 percent of the company and includes a $5 million fund to possibly sue Donald Trump. The commission voted 5-0 Friday for the plan approved early Friday morning by U.S. Bankruptcy Judge Rosemary Gambardella. It still must be approved by the Bahamian government, where Resorts also runs a casino. The plan, filed under Chapter 11 of the U.S. Bankruptcy Code, gives bondholders holding $911 million in bonds 78.5 percent of the company and $434 million in new notes.

Chrysler Corp., which is trying to reduce its salaried work force as a cost-cutting move, is offering nearly all of its 60,000 or so unionized employees money to leave the company. Chrysler spokesman Lee Sechler said Friday that 400 to 450 of the eligible workers had chosen the buyout so far. Another week is left for workers to sign up. The last day of work for anyone choosing to leave will be Aug. 31.

Consumer food prices are going up 5 percent to 7 percent this year, sharply more than had been predicted, the Agriculture Department said. The new forecast Friday compared with the 3 percent to 5 percent price hike the department has been predicting for 1990 since December. Double-digit price gains in the first half of this year for fresh fruits, pork, eggs and dairy products, along with uncertainties about future energy prices, are mostly to blame for the upward revision, the department said.

Foster Grant Corp., whose ads asking which star was behind its sunglasses produced sales and advertising prominence, has sought Chapter 11 bankruptcy court protection from creditors. In papers filed Thursday in U.S. Bankruptcy Court in Tucson, Ariz., the sunglass maker that became popular in the 1960s and '70s reported total assets of about $25 million and liabilities of about $36 million, including nearly $19.3 million in unsecured debt.

FundAmerica Inc., a buying club with 100,000 members, filed for bankruptcy protection from its creditors and asked the court to appoint an independent examiner to investigate various allegations against it. The Irvine, Calif.-based firm is facing scrutiny from regulators in Florida and other states and is the subject of a $150 million class-action suit in San Francisco. Its federal bankruptcy filing Friday in Santa Ana, which had been expected, listed assets of $17.5 million and liabilities of $14.5 million.

Stock prices fell broadly Friday in heavy trading, echoing losses overseas amid continued concern about the Mideast. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 36.64 to 2,644.80, its lowest close since March 1. The dollar sank to another all-time low against the German mark. Bond prices were mixed. Pork futures were mixed, precious metals rose, and grains and soybeans were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: Gulf Crisis Sends Tokyo Markets Reeling
DOC.TEXT: Iraq's invasion of Kuwait sent the already bearish Tokyo stock market plummeting, and traders said the trend is likely to continue. The dollar-yen exchange rate, meanwhile, settled into a range of around 147 to 148 yen to the dollar after major fluctuations early in the crisis. Analysts predicted that the strength of the Japanese economy, and the relative weakness of the U.S. economy, would keep the exchange rate hovering around the same level until the Middle East stalemate breaks. Tokyo's stock traders were already seven months into a bear market by Aug. 2, when Iraqi troops overtook Kuwait. The market, which had been near the 31,000-point level, immediately plunged nearly 600 points. The next two weeks brought new shocks. The first was Japan's decision a few days after the invasion to impose unpredented strict sanctions on Iraq, followed by the United Nations' decision to impose sanctions. The second was Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu's decision the following Monday to cancel his long-planned tour of five Middle Eastern countries, scheduled to begin Aug. 15. Also during the second full week of August, the traditional ``O-bon'' holiday, beautiful weather and the distraction of the national high school baseball tournament, combined to weaken interest in all markets, traders said. On Friday, the 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average closed at 26,786.72 points, down 13 percent from its Aug. 1 close. Traders said the market would continue to slide. ``The most likely scenario for the stock market right now is to weaken further,'' said Pelham Smithers, an analyst for Shearson, Lehman, Hutton Asia, Ltd., citing weakness in the bond market along with uncertainty about the Iraq-Kuwait situation as influences. Low yields on the stock market, he said, ``have made other instruments, such as holding cash, more attractive.'' Long-term interest rates on bonds, for instance, started going up in June, when Japan agreed to spend some $2.72 billion on public works over the next 10 years, he said. The yield of the benchmark 10-year Japanese government bond closed Friday at 8.050 percent, up from 7.505 percent on Aug. 1. The market has been on a long-term downswing since Dec. 29, when the latest postwar ``Superbowl'' market peaked at 38,916 points, said Darrel Whitten, director of research at the Tokyo office of Prudential Bache Securities. Superbowl markets, when markets typically expanded by about 5.5 percent, have been followed by corrections averaging 80 to 90 months, he said. ``The question is how long the adjustment will last.'' Another indicator, the five-year moving average, suggests the market will bottom out at 25,000-21,000 points, he said. With higher oil prices killing any chance of bringing interest rates down, and corporate profits unlikely to go up, ``The blow-off comes in the market,'' he said. Early in the crisis, Japan's near total dependence on imported oil buoyed the dollar. Brent Crude for October delivery closed Friday at about $26.10 to $26.20 a barrel in Tokyo, compared with $19.90 to $21.00 a barrel in New York on Aug. 1. But eventually the markets valued the yen higher because of Japan's economic strength. Although the dollar normally gains strength in times of crisis, the structural weaknesses of the U.S. economy has overwhelmed its traditional strength in times of crisis, many traders said. Japan has been working since the first oil shocks of the early 1970s to broaden its list of suppliers and lessen its dependence on oil imports through efficiency and use of other energy sources, notably nuclear, they said. ``The yen appears to have settled temporarily into a trading range against the U.S. dollar and the Deutschemark, and the earlier pattern of dollar weakness is not expected to re-emerge until the Middle East situation is clarified,'' said analysts at Salomon Brothers Asia, Ltd., in a newsletter prepared for the week of Aug. 13. The dollar closed at 147.35 yen to the U.S. dollar Friday. On Aug. 2, the currency jumped 2.25 yen to 147.13 yen. Closing figures bounced between 149 yen and 150 yen but no higher than 150.65 yen in subsequent days. With energy prices already high, oil and utility company profits would cushion the Japanese economy, while the United States economy is struggling under numerous burdens, added analyst Robert A Feldman.

DOC.HEAD: Press Releases Enter the Age of Video
LaserPhoto HF1 of Aug. 20.
Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: When Spalding Sports Worldwide wanted to entice television journalists into doing stories on its new Top-Flite golf ball, the company knew sending out a few typed pages and a photograph or two wouldn't be enough. So Spalding put out a video, joining the growing number of companies that are turning to ``video news releases'' to promote their products. Known as ``VNRs,'' the 90-second spots have become an electronic alternative to standard news releases. Spalding's VNR cost just $10,000 to make _ compared to the hundreds of thousands of dollars a commercial can cost _ but ended up reaching more than six million viewers, according to Steven Shaw, president of Visual Concepts Media Inc., a Bloomfield company that produced and distributed the video. First, the video was distributed to local television stations across the country. Then Spalding's new golf ball made the national airwaves when, after seeing the video, the ``Today'' show did its own story on game-improvement equipment. ``It was an opportunity for us to be associated with a tremendous growth in the game of golf without being blatantly commercial,'' said J. Greg Sherry, a spokesman for Spalding, based in Chicopee, Mass. Publicity-hungry corporations have been sending public relations film to local stations since the advent of television in the 1940s. But VNRs only began to enjoy a boom in popularity in the mid-1980s, when the proliferation of satellite dishes made them easier to distribute and local news shows needed more material to fill longer, one-hour formats. Most VNRs closely resemble news stories, complete with interviews and narration. The product being hawked is presented, but only as part of what appears as a larger news story. The Spalding video is presented as a story about how high-tech sporting equipment can improve the performance of weekend athletes. Professional and weekend golfers were interviewed about what they look for in a golf ball. Greg Norman, without ever endorsing or even mentioning the Top-Flite ball, tells the viewer that the average golfer should simply find a ball he likes and stick with it. But after his interview, the camera zooms in on one of Spalding's ``Top-Flite Plus II'' balls. For a cost of between $10,000 and $20,000, a VNR _ which typically runs about 90 seconds _ can be beamed to newsrooms around the country via satellite. The use of VNRs remains a controversial topic in the television news industry. Many news directors question the objectivity of a corporate-produced video and claim to have rigid policies against using them. ``They're great for the company, but they're terrible for viewers because they're biased,'' said Paul Frega, news director of WVIT-TV in New Britain. Deborah Johnson, assistant news director at WFSB-TV in Hartford, added: ``They're not useful to us because they are no different than a press release.'' Johnson and Frega acknowledge that their stations sometimes use a small film clip from a VNR for background footage that might be difficult to get on their own. Both news directors cringe, however, when asked if they ever use unedited versions. ``We never, ever use those,'' said Frega. ``I think it's kind of sad that some stations do.'' Such hostility comes as something of a surprise to those who produce VNRs, who say many stations use them, despite their disclaimers. ``It's a holier-than-thou attitude,'' said Douglas Brush, executive vice president of D-J Brush Associates, a New York consulting firm specializing in corporate communications. ``News directors do not like to admit they use prepared material,'' Brush said. ``But the fact of the matter is there are cutbacks in the television news industry, and despite what they tell you, many of them welcome well-prepared video releases.'' Medialink, a New York-based public relations firm that is the nation's largest distributor of video news releases, commissioned a poll in February to find out whether news stations were using VNRs. James Gold, Medialink's managing editor, said 78 percent of news directors and producers who responded to the Nielsen poll said they used edited material from a video news release an average of once a week. Gold, whose company distributed 1,200 VNRs last year, said most of the videos provided television stations with story ideas they later developed themselves. Usually, only a small portion of the video news release ends up being used in the news broadcasts. ``If used responsibly, there's nothing wrong with them,'' said Gold. At Visual Concepts, Shaw and partner Ric Serrenho, both former staffers for WTNH-TV in New Haven, say they are amazed when local stations claim they never use VNRs. ``I really take offense to that,'' says Serrenho. ``We're not forcing anybody to take this product. It has to be a legitimate news story.'' Industry analysts, however, say most television news stations still view VNRs with skepticism because of their inherent public relations slant. ``These people are not stupid. They know a commercial when they see it,'' said James Kaminsky, editor of Corporate Video Decisions, a magazine that covers the corporate video industry. Despite the war of words between news directors and video producers, VNRs are becoming a lucrative cottage industry within the corporate video industry. Today, VNRs account for anywhere from $60 to $100 million of the corporate video industry, according to industry estimates. Medialink's survey showed that last year, approximately 3,500 VNRs were produced across the country. ``It's big and getting bigger,'' Kaminsky said.

DOC.HEAD: Trump And Gambling Agency Differ Over His Casino Future
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Donald Trump blames troubles at his three casinos on a faltering economy and believes his latest deal will give them time to rebound. State officials disagree. The Division of Gaming Enforcement says mismanagement and the opening in April of Trump's Taj Mahal Casino Resort are to blame. And a report by the gaming division for the state Casino Control Commission holds out little hope for a long-term turnaround apart from Trump's request for approval of a plan to put up his casinos as collateral for an emergency $65 million loan. Trump pledged the casinos as security for the loan as part of a restructuring of the casinos' $1 billion debt. The banks agreed in June to lend him the $65 million so he could make an overdue $43 million bond payment on Trump Castle Casino Resort By The Bay. A Trump attorney says the loan is in escrow awaiting the commission's decision. The gaming division reluctantly recommended the commission approve the plan Tuesday, but it attached 13 reporting conditions. And it said the deal, which is part of Trump's scramble to handle the $3.2 billion in debt he has amassed to build his fortunes here and in New York, is no guarantee of success. ``These agreements, even if approved and strictly adhered to by the parties, do not and will not bring to a conclusion the financial difficulties facing the Trump Organization,'' said the report, released on the first day of commission hearings Thursday. The report said mistakes in loading the casinos and Trump's real estate and airline holdings with so much debt might force the developer to shed assets and concentrate on rallying a few core assets. ``Excessive debt has acted as a powerful agent for change and, ironically, has acted as a brake on management mistakes,'' the report said. According to second-quarter casino reports released Wednesday by the Casino Association, the Taj Mahal lost $14 million in its first three months ended June 30, Trump Castle lost $8 million last quarter and Trump Plaza Hotel and Casino recorded an $863,000 profit. The division blames the new Taj Mahal, in part, for accelerating Trump Castle's decline and weakening the previously solid Trump Plaza. The Taj Mahal has hovered around its break-even point of $1.3 million a day during the busy summer months, leaving Trump's remaining casinos and the city's other gaming halls to split the remaining business. Trump conceded Friday that perhaps the Taj Mahal had ``cannibalized'' some of the business directed at his other two casinos. But he repeated his claim that none of his gaming halls is for sale, saying the Taj Mahal merely had the misfortune to open in a stagnant gaming market and a recession striking especially hard in the Northeast. ``Had the Taj Mahal opened in a good economy, the other casinos would not have been hurt,'' Trump said. ``Atlantic City business is down. When you have something opening in a bad economy ... you're looking at a whole different ball game.'' Ed Tracy, president of Trump's casinos and non-casino hotel here, said the Taj Mahal has taken some business away from the city's other gaming halls but that he expected the situation to turn around within six months. The gaming division is unwilling to wait. If the commission approves the plan Tuesday, the panel wants Trump's chief financial officer to return within three weeks with details of how a $47 million bond payment due Nov. 15 on the Taj Mahal will be made. ``The Taj Mahal will be faced with a crisis similar to that recently experienced by Trump Castle unless the Trump Organization directly and expeditiously addresses this matter with the bondholders,'' the report said. Trump acknowledges he has problems but said the latest deal will allow him to recover. ``The whole Northeast has been affected,'' Trump said. ``Unfortunately, I'm the only one everybody writes about.''
